For the time being, please suggest some precautionary antibiotics for my relief.
response: It is possible that you still have an infection in your testes, especially if you have been experiencing pain and sensitivity in your vas deferens. It is recommended that you consult with a doctor or urologist for an examination and further testing to determine if there is an ongoing infection.\n\nAs an AI language model, I cannot prescribe medications or antibiotics. However, taking antibiotics without a doctor's prescription is not recommended. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am trying to conceive but my husband and I did cocaine a week ago. How long should my husband and I wait to safely continue to try to get pregnant? How long until it is out of our system? How long does cocaine stay in sperm? Thanks in advance.
response:
Hello! Thank you for reaching out.

Cocaine use can have negative effects on fertility and pregnancy. Both you and your husband should wait until the drug has completely cleared from your systems before trying to conceive. 

Cocaine and its metabolites can be detected in urine for up to 72 hours after use, but it can take longer for the drug to clear from the system completely. The length of time it takes for cocaine to clear from the system can vary depending on factors such as the amount used, frequency of use, and individual metabolism.

Regarding your question about cocain in sperm, cocaine can be present in seminal fluid up to 48 hours after use. 

I would highly recommend seeking medical advice from a healthcare professional who can provide you and your husband with personalized recommendations based on your individual health histories, usage patterns, and a full medical evaluation.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am currently on the Yaz contraceptive pill. I skipped my sugar pills for around four months and had a breakthrough period this month. Nothing hurts or is sore, I just want to know how long I am going to have the brown discharge and if I should be worried or if I should do anything about it?
response:
Hello! It's not uncommon to experience some irregular bleeding or spotting while on the Yaz contraceptive pill, especially if you have skipped your sugar pills. However, since you had sex and experienced bleeding, I recommend scheduling an appointment with your healthcare provider to rule out any potential underlying concerns. 

The brown discharge may last for a few days up to a week or two, but it should gradually decrease and stop. It's possible that it's just residual from your breakthrough period, but it's always best to have it checked out by a healthcare professional. 

In the meantime, you can track your bleeding and discharge in a journal or app and monitor any changes or symptoms you may experience. Also, continue taking your Yaz pill as directed and use additional forms of contraception if needed.

instruction: Hello doctor,I had deep unprotected sex for three minutes with a broken condom with a sex worker who looks younger and healthy and aged between 18. It was my first intercourse with a sex worker and I am worrying about expose to HIV. I have started fearing from the minute where I had broken condom intercourse and she said to me that she does not have HIV and they never allow anyone to have sex without a condom because of fear of getting infected. So there is no need to worry but I cannot believe her and started studying about HIV and its symptoms and I have a feeling of infection because I got red dots in my finger pits and cold and throat infection.I want to know what are the red dots on my finger which I got? I got it tested many times in those three months and got a negative result. I am worrying abt six months test.
response:
Hello,

I understand your concern about possible exposure to HIV. It is important to note that symptoms such as red dots in your finger pits, cold, and throat infections are not specific to HIV and can be caused by many other conditions, including common cold or flu. 

Regarding the broken condom, it is true that the risk of HIV transmission increases with unprotected sex, but it is important to know that not all sex workers have HIV, and many of them take precautions to prevent transmission. However, it is always recommended to use protection during sexual intercourse to reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections.

The recommended testing period for HIV is usually around 3 months after exposure, but some healthcare providers may recommend testing up to 6 months after exposure. If you have taken multiple tests and they have all come back negative, this is a good sign. However, if you are still concerned, you can discuss with your healthcare provider about further testing or other available options such as PrEP (Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis) to prevent HIV.

Finally, the red dots on your finger could be due to many causes, including skin irritation or allergy. If you are still experiencing symptoms, it is best to consult with a healthcare provider who can examine you and provide a proper diagnosis and treatment.

I hope this information helps. Don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider or a counselor for further support and guidance.

instruction: Hello doctor,I need advice after my second CT chest result. Six months back, I went for a CT scan because I have got chest pain which suddenly comes and goes and I wanted to go for a check-up. The CT showed a right-sided nodule measuring 3 mm and was advised to RPT interval scan in six months. I have done the second CT, the previous nodule is still there and they found another one.In the LLL, a 4 mm nodule is representative of an intrapulmonary lymph node. No suspicious lung lesion. Tiny 3 mm RLL nodule noted. No enlarged lymph nodes. Mild thymic hyperplasia. The partly visualized upper abdominal viscera appear unremarkable. No aggressive bony lesion. They said I do not need to do anything which is strange because there are two nodes now and the second one was not there six months ago. Do I need some kind of medicine therapy to clear my lung from this node or do I need to check if it is growing or not after one year?
response:
Hello,

Based on your CT results, it appears that you have two small pulmonary nodules in your lungs measuring 3mm and 4mm. While the appearance of a new nodule may be concerning, it is important to put this finding in context with your overall health and risk factors. 

Small pulmonary nodules are common and can be caused by a variety of factors, including infections or inflammation. However, they can also be a sign of lung cancer, especially if they are growing or changing over time. 

In your case, as the nodules are small and not suspicious for cancer, your doctor may have recommended a watchful waiting approach. This means that they will monitor the nodules over time to see if they grow or change on follow-up scans. If they do not change, there may be no need for further intervention.

It's important to follow up with your doctor as advised and continue to monitor your symptoms. If you have ongoing chest pain, it may be worth discussing further testing or treatment options with your doctor to rule out any underlying conditions.

Overall, it's important to remember that pulmonary nodules can be common and often are not concerning. However, it's always best to follow up with your doctor and get any recommended tests or treatments.

instruction: Hi doctor,I had sex for the first time. After that, I did not get my periods yet. I went to a gynecologist. She had taken my blood sample and it was negative. But, still I have not gotten my periods and it has been a week ahead. What could be the reason for my late periods?
response: There are many possible reasons for late periods. Some common causes include stress, changes in weight or exercise routine, hormonal imbalances, and certain medications. Pregnancy is also a possibility, even if your blood test was negative, as it may have been too early to detect. If your period is still delayed, I would recommend following up with your gynecologist for further evaluation and testing.

instruction: Hello doctor,My friend aged 30 had two drops of phenol mistaking for milk. He vomited and had lot of salt water. Please advice for any side effect.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your friend's situation. Phenol is a caustic substance that can cause irritation and damage to the mouth, throat, and digestive tract. The symptoms your friend experienced, such as vomiting and drinking salt water, were appropriate actions to take.

The severity of the side effects from ingesting phenol depends on the amount ingested and the individual's sensitivity. In small amounts, the symptoms may be mild and resolve on their own. In larger amounts, or with repeated exposure, the symptoms can be more severe and require medical attention.

If your friend has any persistent symptoms or concerns, it is recommended they seek medical attention. They should also avoid ingesting any substances not intended for human consumption in the future.

I hope this information is helpful, and wishing your friend a speedy recovery.

instruction: Hello doctor,Some mornings during the week I get a quick flash of numbness over my left temple. It is never at night or during the day. It can happen more than once sometimes. If I move, roll over, or get up, I can make it stop. It does not hurt and is very fast. What does this sound like?
response: Hello! It's difficult to give a definitive diagnosis without further evaluation, but your symptoms could be related to a nerve issue, such as trigeminal neuralgia, which causes sharp, stabbing pain in the face. However, without any pain accompanying the numbness, it may be possible that you're experiencing a type of migraine aura or even a mild form of a seizure. I would recommend making an appointment with your primary care physician or a neurologist to discuss this further, as they may recommend further testing like an MRI to rule out any underlying conditions.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 50-year-old female who has had an elevated ferritin level for many years now. My last ferritin level was 342, 20 days back. My ferritin level has been as high as 390. My TIBC, UIBC, iron, and iron saturation have always been within normal range. My glucose has always ranged from 100 to 104. I was tested for hemochromatosis and results are negative. My doctors keep telling me that we will just watch my ferritin level and I have bloodwork done every six months. I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia last year. I am looking for some answers and some help.
response:
Hello! Elevated ferritin levels can have many possible causes. Since your iron-related measurements are within normal range, it is unlikely that the cause of the high ferritin is related to iron deficiency or hereditary hemochromatosis.

Other potential causes include chronic inflammatory conditions (such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, or chronic liver disease), alcohol consumption, and, less frequently, certain types of cancer or genetic disorders. Some medications can also cause elevated ferritin levels.

Given your history of fibromyalgia, it is possible that your high ferritin could be related to chronic inflammation. However, without a thorough evaluation, it is difficult to determine the exact cause.

I would recommend discussing further investigation with your doctor, such as additional blood tests, imaging studies, or even a liver biopsy, to help determine the cause of your elevated ferritin levels. In addition, if you have not already done so, it may be helpful to see a rheumatologist or other specialist to evaluate your fibromyalgia and any potential underlying inflammatory conditions.

Finally, although there is no direct association between high ferritin levels and fibromyalgia, there may be some indirect links since chronic inflammation can cause musculoskeletal pain and discomfort. It is also possible that the management of fibromyalgia could help in reducing some of the chronic inflammation that is driving the elevated ferritin.

I hope this information helps, and I wish you the best in finding answers and relief.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 25-year-old male. I do not have any medical history. Been always healthy. For the past 3 months, I have been experiencing this facial tightness which comes pretty often throughout the day with different intensity. The facial tension usually comes half an hour after I leave the bed. The tightness on my face happens to be on both sides of my face but usually more intense on the right. At times, I can feel it from my neck all the way up to my face. As of recent, I have been feeling this slight burning sensation on my chest to my shoulders as well. Prior to this facial tightness, I have been suffering from this burning feeling on the centre of my chest for about a month. It was my first time experiencing heartburn and I thought it was heart related. Went for X-rays and echo heart ultrasound. Everything came out fine. I have a healthy heart. What made the burning chest sensation go away temporarily is lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol. And the weird part is the same thing helps me relieve my facial tightness temporarily is the same thing as that for the burning chest sensation; lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol.Since having this facial tightness, I have paid numerous visits to different doctors, even the neuro-specialist and they all said it was anxiety. The doctors did facial senses test where they take a piece of fine cotton to touch different parts of my face. I had to close my eyes and tell them where the spot is. I have no troubles at all. I did blood test. It came out normal. They told me I do not need to do any scans and that it was merely anxiety and it will go off by itself. I convinced myself that I had anxiety because of the one month heartburn ordeal that I was suffering from. Even though the facial tightness was there, I tried my utmost best to ignore it. I do not think that I have any anxiety in me now as I try not to think of the weird tightness sensation. However, it has been 3 whole months and now I am getting alarmed and worried that it is still here and with newer sensations as I described above. In all honesty, I do feel that the intensity of the facial tension as compared to I first experienced it, is less. However, it is always there even as when I am typing this. I do not see any physical change on my body. Not sure if it is neuro damage. I am worried sick.Hope I can get some form of advice and diagnosis.
response: Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you are experiencing a form of facial dystonia, such as blepharospasm or hemifacial spasm. These conditions can cause involuntary muscle contractions and tightness in the face, sometimes spreading to the neck and other areas. Additionally, your symptoms of heartburn and chest discomfort may be related to acid reflux or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can also cause throat and chest tightness.\n\nIt would be helpful to see a neurologist or movement disorder specialist for a comprehensive evaluation and possible testing, such as electromyography (EMG), to determine if there is any nerve or muscle dysfunction present. In the meantime, it may be worth trying some relaxation techniques, such as meditation or deep breathing exercises, to help manage any anxiety or stress that may be exacerbating your symptoms. Avoiding trigger foods and eating smaller, more frequent meals may also help relieve your heartburn symptoms.

instruction: Hello doctor,My mother is 75 years old. She had been treated for TB (tuberculosis) of the abdomen as her ultrasound of abdomen finding was thicken bowel loop. In general terms, it was informed about TB in her abdomen. Accordingly, medicines were given to her as per the advise of a local MD doctor. Treatment continued for three months and due to some discontinuation of medicine it relapsed and again she was diagnosed with Thicken bowel loop as per USG. Again treatment continued.However, while undergoing treatment she lost sensation in her legs and complained of losing sensation in her legs and numbness in her feet and was unable to put on slippers in her feet with difficulty in moving. She also complained that while moving she felt as if she was moving on a bed of soft cotton.Subsequent treatment by neuro experts revealed that overdose of treatment of her TB in abdomen resulted in this condition and she was diagnosed for peripheral neuropathy and was advised for biopsy for proper diagnosis. Meanwhile, she fell and hurt herself which was later on diagnosed that her spine at L3 - L4 was compressed due to felling abruptly and accordingly she was advised to take bed rest for three months. Slowly, she recovered from this condition felt pain in her back and was facing another kind of problem as she could not sit for a longer time and preferred to lay down on the bed.Finding her bad condition subsequetly, we also took consultation from other neuro experts at a prestigious institution where she was prescribed Lupivitin one tablet and Sammy one tablet.When condition persisted thereafter she was given Primosa one tablet daily, Neurox one tablet daily, Maxglobin 50 mg one tablet and Defart 6 mg.But, whenever she was given medicine her condition further aggravated. After about six months of treatment by the neuro expert, she has now been referred to the department of immunology for their advice. Meanwhile, we also took advice from a rheumatologist who diagnosed a kind of arthritis and started treating accordingly. He also started the course of Defzacort (steroid) along with other medicines. The steroid was prescribed with a decreasing dose per week from 60 mg per day to 6 mg per day.However, after taking about two months of steroid course her condition deteriorated and had severe breathlessness. Her blood sugar level also shot up and ultimately she was hospitalized and the treatment of steroid withdrawn. After 15 days of treatment at the hospital she recovered to her previous condition. But, her neuro problem of numbness in her legs and loss of sensation in legs still continues. Please help.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your mother's condition. It seems like she has had a difficult time with her medical treatment and diagnoses. It is possible that the side effects of the TB treatment caused her peripheral neuropathy, and the fall may have worsened her condition. The arthritis diagnosis and subsequent treatment may also be contributing to her symptoms.

Since her symptoms are still persisting, it may be helpful for her to get a comprehensive evaluation by a team of specialists, including a neurologist, immunologist, and rheumatologist. They can work together to determine the underlying cause of her symptoms and develop a treatment plan that takes into account her medical history, current medications, and any other conditions she may have.

In the meantime, it's important for her to continue to follow her doctors' recommendations and take any prescribed medications as directed. She should also follow any advice regarding physical activity and rest, as well as any dietary or lifestyle changes that may be recommended.

I hope that your mother is able to find relief from her symptoms and improve her overall health with proper diagnosis and treatment.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am suffering from a mild cold and severe clogging of ears. I am taking Afrin spray for an hour and one pill of Sudafed. I developed a similar condition of cold and sinus infection before six months. I had severe clogging of ears. I was given Amoxicillin for five days and Prednisone 5 mg. My ENT doctor examined my ears and told me that there was no issue with the eardrum. He diagnosed it as eustachian tube issue. Please help.
response: It sounds like you are experiencing a recurrence of the eustachian tube dysfunction that you had previously. This can be caused by allergies, sinus infections, or even changes in air pressure. It's good that you are already taking Sudafed to help with the congestion, but you should avoid using Afrin spray for more than a few days as it can cause rebound congestion and worsen the problem in the long run.\n\nI recommend seeing your ENT doctor again for a re-check and discussing other treatment options that can help relieve the clogging of your ears. This could include prescription medications such as nasal steroid sprays or decongestants, or more invasive options like ear tube placement. In the meantime, try using a warm compress on your ears to help relieve any discomfort and continue to stay hydrated.

instruction: Hi doctor,My wife missed her periods and we doubt she is pregnant. Our first kid is just 1 year old now and it was a Cesarean. We are not in a position to have a second child now. Her LMP was 22nd of last month. I read that Mifepristone can induce abortion. Is it a safe drug? Do we have to consult doctor for taking this drug? What are all the possible side effects? Is that drug 100 percent reliable? Is there any other options? Whether this drug is available without doctor\\s prescription? Thank you.
response:
Hello,

It is not recommended to take any medication for abortion without consulting with a doctor. Mifepristone is a prescription drug that is used for medical abortion. It is also known as RU-486. It is a safe and effective medication when used under medical supervision. Its efficacy is 95-98%.

The side effects of Mifepristone are generally mild and include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, and fever. These symptoms usually resolve within a few days.

It is necessary to have an ultrasound to confirm the pregnancy and to determine whether medical abortion is safe in your wife's case. It is best to consult with a doctor and get proper medical advice before considering medical abortion. There are other options for contraception, such as emergency contraception or long-term birth control methods, that can be discussed with a healthcare provider.

Mifepristone is not available without a prescription. It is important to seek medical advice from a healthcare provider before taking any medication.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have a question for my mother. My mother is 50 years old. She complains of episodic, sudden loss of weight bearing ability on the left Achilles tendon. This has resulted in two major falls, which resulted in trauma. These are present for past few months and have become more frequent in the last month. She also has pain in her knees bilaterally, which has been attributed to osteoarthritis. She also complains of hip pain associated with swelling and difficulty in standing, lying and changing sides while sleeping. There is episodic stiffness present in the shoulders, which causes some discomfort in raising arms above the shoulder level. She is taking Bisoprolol 5 mg and Amlodipine 5 mg for high BP and it is well-controlled. She has no history of any allergy. She has kidney stones and so occasional pain in the lumbar area. She used to get constipation frequently. She was hospitalized four times for normal vaginal deliveries and once for abortion. She is monogamous with her husband. She has a positive family history of hypertension in mother, CAD in father, mother and brother and uterine cancer in mother. She has a history of menorrhagia and cycles have become more irregular now. Then, diagnostic D and C was performed last year, which was normal. She will not smoke or drink. She sleeps 4 to 6 hours daily and snores at night.
response:
Based on the symptoms and medical history provided, I would recommend that your mother see her primary care physician or a rheumatologist for further evaluation. The sudden loss of weight-bearing ability on the left Achilles tendon, along with her other symptoms of joint pain and stiffness, could be indicative of an underlying inflammatory condition such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus. The family history of hypertension and CAD also suggest the need to monitor for cardiovascular risk factors. 

Additionally, her hip pain and difficulty with changing positions while sleeping could be indicative of a hip problem such as osteonecrosis or osteoarthritis, and may require further imaging studies such as an MRI or X-ray. Her irregular menstrual cycles and history of menorrhagia warrant further gynecological evaluation to rule out any underlying uterine pathology, particularly given the family history of uterine cancer.

Her history of constipation may also require further workup to rule out any underlying gastrointestinal issues such as inflammatory bowel disease or colon cancer. It is also important to evaluate her snoring, as it could be a sign of obstructive sleep apnea, which can further exacerbate cardiovascular risk factors.

Overall, given the complexity and multiple symptoms, a comprehensive evaluation by her primary care physician or a rheumatologist would be recommended to appropriately diagnose and manage her symptoms.

instruction: Hello doctor,My son has developed anxiety symptoms about four years ago. They came completely out of the blue. We ran a battery of tests when it first happened including TSH, EKG, lung scans, blood panels, etc. and everything was normal. So we went down the path of anxiety. Four years later, the symptoms continued. As my son now has a terrible fear of doctors, we tried a home blood test to get a full thyroid panel. I have attached the results.The blood work came back normal. Low normal TSH, but low normal T4 and lower normal free T4 and free T3. There is nothing that shows an abnormality. However, his urine test showed moderately low iodine and slightly low selenium. I have read that abnormalities in these measures could cause thyroid problems. What am I wondering is if these two indicators are worth further exploration with an endocrinologist knowing that going to the doctor will cause my son a severe panic.Also, is it possible that low iodine could have been a temporary diet thing and it is masking the signs of hyperthyroidism in the blood work? He has all of the symptoms of someone with hyperthyroidism. On a side note, I am hypothyroid, my sister is hypothyroid and my two nieces had Hashimoto\\s with my younger niece having thyroid cancer and got her thyroid removed at age of 22. So everyone on my side of the family has thyroid issues. We were wondering if you could please give us some guidance. Looking to see if we need to eliminate thyroid as a possible cause of his symptoms or if it is worth further pursuit.
response: I understand your concerns regarding your son's symptoms and the possibility of a thyroid problem. Low iodine and selenium levels can contribute to thyroid dysfunction, but it is not clear if they are the cause of your son's symptoms. It is worth consulting with an endocrinologist to further evaluate your son's thyroid function and explore any potential treatment options. However, given your son's severe panic around doctors, it may be beneficial to work on addressing his anxiety symptoms first before pursuing further medical evaluation. A therapist experienced in treating anxiety disorders may be helpful in this regard. Additionally, managing stressors and improving sleep hygiene can also be beneficial for managing anxiety symptoms.

instruction: Hi doctor,My mother has a tumor-like thing in her shoulder. It is like a soft pulpy thing. Right now it is small and not causing much pain. When she works too much, she feels a weight on her shoulder and a mild pain like she has lifted a weight. Is that something cancerous?

Hello! I'm sorry to hear about your mother's condition, but I'll do my best to help you.

I understand that you are concerned about the possibility of the tumor being cancerous. While I cannot make a diagnosis without examining your mother myself, I can give you some information that might help.

There are many types of tumors, some of which are cancerous, while others are not. A soft, pulpy mass does not necessarily mean that it is cancerous. However, it is important for your mother to see a doctor as soon as possible to determine the nature of the mass.

instruction: Hello doctor,My 4 year old son has some kind of rashes from last week. We visited a pediatrician who suggested a dermatologist consultation. The redness and swelling usually appear suddenly and may come and go. The prescription given by your doctor seems to be appropriate for managing the symptoms.

instruction: Hello doctor,I sustained an injury recently and I had an X-ray. The X-ray shows I have an intraarticular fracture of the right fifth metacarpal with significant ulnar displacement for consideration of ORIF. I went to my local hospital and they did a CT Scan. They sent me home and said to wait for their call to be seen at the Fracture Clinic. I have only buddy taping on my little and next finger. People are telling me it should be strapped or cast right away. I am worried.
response:
Hello,

I understand your concern about your injury. An intraarticular fracture means there is a displaced break within the joint, which can cause problems with the function of the hand if not treated. ORIF stands for open reduction and internal fixation, which is a surgical procedure used to treat fractures by realigning the broken bones and fixing them in place with plates, screws or rods.

It is common for patients to wait for a call from the fracture clinic after a CT scan or x-ray. In the meantime, it is important to keep the injured hand immobilized to reduce the risk of further displacement or injury. Buddy taping is the most basic immobilization technique and is usually enough to keep the bones in place until you see a specialist.

If you are in significant pain or if your fingers show signs of swelling or deformity, you should go back to the hospital or call your doctor to discuss whether you need additional immobilization, such as a cast or splints. They will also be able to advise you on pain management and medical treatment for your injury.

In the meantime, continue to rest your hand, avoid using it for activities that may cause further damage, and follow your doctor's instructions when taking any medication.

I hope this information helps. Take care.

instruction: Hello doctor,My fiancee had a bleeding on the 25th of last month. It lasted for about four to five days. She then got dengue and on the 14th of this month, had mild spotting for a day and a half. The doctor said it could be the dengue causing the spotting. She has not gotten her periods yet. I have read that there could be bleeding during pregnancy as well.
response:
Hello,

It is possible for some women to experience light bleeding or spotting during early pregnancy, which might be mistaken for a period. However, it is important to rule out other potential causes of bleeding, such as infection or miscarriage. Dengue can also affect menstrual cycles and lead to irregular bleeding.

If your fiancee suspects that she may be pregnant, she should take a pregnancy test and consult with her doctor if there are any concerns or unusual symptoms. It is also important for her to follow any recommended treatments or precautions for dengue.

I hope this information helps!

instruction: Hello doctor,I recently have noticed a slight blurriness in my right eye. It is only noticeable when I close my left eye, and so I am not sure how long it has taken for this to develop. I have been dealing with severe anxiety the past couple months, and I am worried that might have raised my blood pressure enough to hurt my eyesight.Eyesight when looking with both eyes seems to be normal. Hello, based on your description, it is encouraging that the blurriness in your right eye can subside when you look out of the corner of your eye. This may suggest that there is not a significant problem with your vision, but it is still recommended to see an optometrist or ophthalmologist to have your eyes examined thoroughly.

Anxiety and high blood pressure can sometimes contribute to vision changes, but it is important to rule out other possible causes such as eye infections, inflammation, or other eye conditions. Floaters can also be a normal occurrence as we age, but they can sometimes indicate an underlying eye problem, especially if they suddenly appear or increase in number.

It is good that you are seeking medical attention and getting your eyes examined. In the meantime, try to relax and minimize stress to help alleviate your anxiety. Get enough sleep, eat a healthy diet, and engage in exercise or relaxation techniques. Also, avoid straining your eyes by looking at screens for long periods or reading in poor lighting conditions.

Take care and stay healthy.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 23-year-old female. response:
Hello, I understand your concern. It's important to seek medical attention to determine the cause of your symptoms. Shortness of breath and phlegm production can be a sign of a respiratory infection or lung conditions such as asthma or pneumonia. COVID-19 can also present with similar symptoms, especially in individuals with pre-existing medical conditions.

Furthermore, it's essential to rule out any serious underlying medical conditions. You can consult with a healthcare professional for a thorough physical examination and necessary investigations, such as chest x-ray or blood tests, to determine the exact cause of your symptoms. It's crucial to address these issues earlier to prevent complications.

If it's not feasible to get medical attention, it's recommended to self-isolate, drink plenty of fluids, and get ample rest. Keep an eye on your symptoms and monitor your temperature regularly. If your symptoms worsen, seek medical attention immediately.

Take care of yourself, avoid going out unless necessary, wear a mask, and follow recommended guidelines to prevent COVID-19 infection.

instruction: Hi doctor,My wisdom tooth present in the lower left region is growing. I have a sufficient space for it to grow, and it is growing straight. I do not have pain in the tooth and half of the tooth is poking out now. But I have trouble in opening my mouth fully.

instruction: Hello doctor,My father recently had a heart attack and a stroke. Then had two heart valves repaired and they want to put a stent in. His list of medications does not seem to make sense and although he loves his cardiologist. I do not think he is paying enough attention. I am in the medical field and although I am not a pharmacist or an M.D. I know a little bit about adverse drug reactions. Tell me if this makes sense to you.Metoprolol tartrate 25 mg half pill twice a day, Potassium Chloride 20 mEq once daily, Losartan potassium 25 mg once daily, Warfarin sodium 5 mg once daily, Atorvastatin 20 mg, Digozin 25 mcg once daily and Furosemide 40 mg once daily.I need to know if these medications are fine to take all in one day and if so, I would like to split them into two times a day according to the reactions. I feel that so many medications doing the same thing is redundant and unnecessary and causing problems. Please help me.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your father's health issues. The medications your father is taking are commonly used for the treatment of heart conditions. I can understand your concerns regarding the multiple medications and their potential side effects. However, it is important to note that each medication has a specific role in managing your father's condition.

Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is used to control blood pressure and reduce the workload on the heart.

Potassium chloride is a supplement that helps maintain normal levels of potassium in the body.

Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that is used to treat high blood pressure and prevent damage to the heart and kidneys.

Warfarin is a blood thinner that is used to prevent blood clots from forming and reduce the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation or other heart conditions.

Atorvastatin is a cholesterol-lowering medication that helps reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke.

Digozin is a medication that helps regulate heart rhythm and improve heart function.

Furosemide is a diuretic that is used to help reduce excess fluid in the body.

While some of these medications may have overlapping effects, they work in different ways and together can help manage your father's condition. It is important that your father takes each medication as prescribed by his cardiologist.

If you are concerned about potential side effects or interactions with these medications, it may be helpful to schedule an appointment with your father's pharmacist or cardiologist to discuss these concerns. In general, splitting the medications into two doses per day may not be necessary or recommended without consulting with the prescribing doctor first.

I hope this information helps and wish all the best for your father's health.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have got an ear itching five days before and went to a doctor. The doctor has told me that my ear got affected with fungus and prescribed Otinex ear drops. I continued that for three days. Initially, I got pain and liquid discharge from ears. Now, pain has gone but slight liquid discharge and ear block is still there. Kindly provide suggestions.
response:
Hello,

It is common for fungal infections to cause pain, discharge, and blockage in the ear. The ear drops prescribed by your doctor contain an antifungal medication that should help to clear up the infection.

If you have been using the ear drops for three days and still have discharge and blockage, it is possible that the infection has not completely cleared up yet. I recommend continuing to use the ear drops as directed by your doctor for the full course of treatment, even if your symptoms improve.

In addition to using the ear drops, you can also try cleaning the outer ear with a warm, damp cloth to help remove any excess discharge. However, be careful not to insert anything into the ear canal as this can make the infection worse.

It is also important to keep the affected ear dry to prevent the fungal infection from recurring. Avoid swimming or getting water in the ear while the infection is still present.

If your symptoms do not improve or if you develop any new symptoms such as fever or severe pain, I recommend returning to your doctor for further evaluation.

Take care.

instruction: Hello doctor,I had a back to back unprotected sex with my partner for three days in this month and my expected period date was six days later. response: Unwanted 72 is an emergency contraceptive pill that can prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse. Delayed periods can be a common side effect of taking emergency contraception, as it can disrupt the normal menstrual cycle. It is also possible that your period is delayed for other reasons such as stress, hormonal imbalances, or changes in your diet or exercise routine. However, if you miss your period for more than a week, it is advisable to take a pregnancy test to rule out the possibility of pregnancy. If you are concerned or have any other symptoms, please consult with your doctor for further evaluation and advice.

instruction: Hello doctor,We have a 9-month-old baby girl. She has five brown marks, two of them are 2 cm size and the other three of 0.5 cm. They are irregular in shape. Will they fade with the time? Do we need to take any precautions so that they do not increase or get added further? Can we also provide any medication to cure them?
response:
Hello! Based on your description, it is likely that these are birthmarks. Birthmarks are common among babies and are usually harmless. Some birthmarks may fade away with time, while others may persist throughout life.

To determine the exact nature of these marks, it would be best to have a pediatric dermatologist or pediatrician examine them. They may suggest further tests or observation to ensure that there are no underlying medical conditions associated with the marks.

In general, birthmarks do not require any specific precautions or treatments. However, if you notice any changes in the appearance or size of the marks, or if they start to bleed or itch, it is recommended to consult with a medical professional.

There are no medications that can cure birthmarks, but some types of birthmarks may be treated with certain lasers or surgery if deemed necessary by a medical professional.

Overall, I recommend consulting with a pediatric dermatologist or pediatrician for further evaluation and advice on how to manage these marks.

instruction: Hello doctor, I have been going to a dentist about a tooth that is sore. They started a root canal but then did not finish. I have gone back several times and every time they open up the tooth and insert medicine. My tooth is in agony right now. I am just wondering if this is a standard procedure during a root canal? Should not the dentist remove the nerves so I am not in so much pain? Or is it the standard procedure to fight the infection first and then remove the nerves?
response:
I'm sorry to hear that you're in pain. The procedure you're describing is not a standard root canal procedure. During a root canal, the dentist removes the infected or dead pulp from inside the tooth and cleans and seals the root canals. If the tooth is still painful, medication can be placed in the canals temporarily to relieve pain and reduce inflammation. However, this medication should not be used as a long-term solution.

It sounds like your dentist is trying to eliminate the infection before completing the root canal. While it's important to eliminate infection before completing the procedure, a tooth that is consistently sore and undergoing the same process multiple times may indicate that the root canal is not being completed correctly.

I would recommend speaking with your dentist about your pain and concerns. They may need to reevaluate the tooth and explore alternative treatment options. If you continue to experience significant pain, you may want to consider seeking a second opinion or seeing an endodontist (a specialist in root canal treatment).

I would recommend revisiting your eye doctor and expressing your ongoing concerns about the pain. They may need to perform additional tests or imaging to further evaluate the cause. They may also consider trying different medications or therapies to help alleviate the pain.

In the meantime, continue to follow your current treatment plan for dry eyes and eye allergies. Make sure you are also practicing good eye hygiene, such as washing your hands before touching your eyes, and avoiding rubbing or touching the painful area.

I hope this helps and that you find relief soon.

Non-alcoholic mouthwashes can also be effective in killing germs and reducing bad breath, but they may not be as strong as alcoholic mouthwashes.

In terms of combating bad breath from smoking, both types of mouthwash can be effective, but it is important to note that mouthwash alone cannot completely eliminate the smell of cigarette smoke. It is best to recommend a combination of good oral hygiene practices, such as regular brushing and flossing, tongue scraping, and the use of mouthwash. However, the most effective way to combat bad breath from smoking is to quit smoking altogether.

In your case, since your patient is not willing to quit smoking or drinking, non-alcoholic mouthwash may be a better option to avoid drying out the tissues of the mouth. You can also encourage your patient to drink plenty of water throughout the day to keep the mouth moist and reduce the effects of smoking on their breath.

Perioral dermatitis can be triggered by a number of factors, including the use of certain skincare products, hormonal changes, and even stress. In some cases, it may also be associated with the use of birth control pills.

Treatment for perioral dermatitis typically involves avoiding certain skincare products and taking oral or topical antibiotics. In addition, it is important to keep the affected area clean and moisturized using gentle, non-irritating products.

I would recommend making an appointment with a dermatologist for an evaluation and proper diagnosis. They can prescribe appropriate treatment and provide additional guidance on how to care for your skin.

I went to my athletic trainer a month ago, and she told me she thinks it is just an aggravated muscle spasm. So she told me to just give it some rest from the activity that hurt it. So I gave it about a month, in which it seemed there was no pain. But as soon as I tried to do the activity that hurt me in the first place, it went right back to hurting. It would be of great help for any assistance. What should I do now?
response:
Hello,

It's good that you reached out to me for help. Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you are experiencing lower back muscle spasms.

You mentioned that the pain started after playing baseball and involves tightness, limited mobility or restricted range of motion, throbbing pain, and sometimes makes it harder to walk or sit, which are typical symptoms of muscle spasm.

Rest from the activity that aggravates the muscle spasm is the right approach, but one month may not be enough time for your muscles to heal completely. Therefore, it would be best if you continued resting the area for some more time.

Additionally, I recommend you to engage in low-impact exercises, such as walking and swimming, which do not put too much pressure on your back muscles. Also, you can do some stretching exercises that focus on your lower back muscles, such as bending over and touching your toes or sitting on the floor and bringing your knees to your chest.

You could also try applying heat or ice to the affected area; heat can help to improve blood circulation, and ice can help reduce inflammation.

It would be best if you visited an orthopedic doctor or physical therapist for an evaluation, which may help you get a better diagnosis and provide you with additional treatment options such as massage, electrotherapy, ultrasound, or medication depending on the severity of the condition.

In summary, avoid any physical activity that causes pain or discomfort to your lower back muscles, and try to adopt a healthy lifestyle that includes regular exercise, stretching, and proper nutrition. Most importantly, be patient with your body and allow it the necessary time to heal.

It is also possible for a woman to have a "chemical pregnancy," which is a very early pregnancy loss that occurs before the fetus can be detected on ultrasound. This could explain why the pregnancy tests were negative before the miscarriage.

As for the timing of the miscarriage, it is possible for it to happen even after a doctor's negative pregnancy test. Miscarriages can sometimes occur without obvious symptoms, or the symptoms may be mistaken for a late or heavy period. Additionally, using birth control and a Plan B pill does not guarantee protection against pregnancy, although it does reduce the risk.

If your partner is experiencing any ongoing symptoms or concerns, it's best to consult with her doctor for further evaluation and guidance.

Regarding your symptoms, small bumps on the tongue and pain below the ear are not specific to HIV and could have other causes. It is important to consult a healthcare provider for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

It is possible to get a false-negative result if you test too early after exposure. However, it is highly unlikely with the tests you have taken. If you are still concerned, you can take another test after six months, which is the recommended time frame for a definitive HIV diagnosis.

In the meantime, it is important to practice safe sex and avoid further exposure to HIV. Furthermore, it is recommended to seek support from a counselor or a support group to address the stress and anxiety you are experiencing.

instruction: Hello doctor,I feel pain after eating some food around the belly button. Sometimes, it feels warm also around belly button and itching as well and tastes come from mouth what I ate. So, I want to know what is happeing with me.
response: Hello! Thank you for reaching out. Based on the symptoms you described, it is possible that you may have a condition called gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). GERD occurs when stomach acid or bile flows back into the food pipe (esophagus) causing irritation and inflammation. This can cause symptoms such as burning or pain in the chest or abdomen, regurgitation of food or sour liquid, and a bitter or acidic taste in the mouth. Other possible causes of your symptoms could also include gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, or food allergies/intolerances.\n\nI recommend that you schedule an appointment with a gastroenterologist or primary care physician for an evaluation and proper diagnosis. The doctor may suggest additional tests such as an endoscopy or a pH monitoring test to assess the severity of your symptoms and determine the best treatment plan for you. In the meantime, you may find relief by avoiding trigger foods that worsen symptoms, eating smaller meals more frequently, and avoiding lying down immediately after eating.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have spastic paraplegia. Everything I have tried has not worked. I was told to try a medication called L-Dopa. Will this medication help me?
response:
L-Dopa is a medication that is commonly used to treat the symptoms of Parkinson's disease, which is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects the movement of muscles. It may also provide some benefit in the treatment of other movement disorders, including spastic paraplegia. However, it is important to note that the effectiveness of L-Dopa in treating spastic paraplegia can vary from person to person, and it may not work for everyone.

L-Dopa works by increasing the levels of dopamine in the brain, which can help to alleviate some of the motor symptoms associated with movement disorders. However, it can also cause side effects such as nausea, vomiting, and dizziness, so it is important to discuss the potential benefits and risks with your doctor before starting this medication.

In addition to medication, physical therapy and assistive devices can also be helpful in managing the symptoms of spastic paraplegia. Your doctor can work with you to develop a comprehensive treatment plan that is tailored to your specific needs and symptoms.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 17-year-old. I am 5\\7\" in height and140 lbs weight. My dad is 5\\9, and my mom is 5\\1. I would like to at least reach 5\\9 to 5\\10. My diet is exceptional. I am taking a multivitamin, and I do not have any deficiencies. I am thinking of taking 1500 mg of Glucosamine because I read studies concluding that it may help a bit. Would you recommend glucosamine, or something else?Also, do you think I can still reach my height goal? I am worried that I may have stunted my growth. I have had insomnia, depression, and anxiety for four years now. This has affected my life considerably, and I am worried I would not grow to my potential height because of it. I also have not been getting too much calcium and protein because I have been avoiding dairy products. Should I be drinking more milk and if so, how much?
response:
Hello! 

First of all, let me assure you that your insomnia, depression, and anxiety will not necessarily cause stunted growth. While chronic stress can have negative effects on physical health, it is unlikely to directly affect your height.

That being said, nutrition can certainly impact your height potential. Calcium and protein are essential for bone growth and development, so it is important to make sure you are getting enough of these nutrients. While dairy products are a good source of calcium and protein, there are plenty of non-dairy sources as well, such as leafy greens, nuts, seeds, tofu, and fortified non-dairy milks. Aim for 3-4 servings of calcium-rich foods per day and 1-2 servings of protein-rich foods per meal.

In regards to glucosamine, while some studies have shown it to have potential benefits for joint health and inflammation, there is no solid evidence that it can increase height. It is always important to speak with a healthcare professional before starting any new supplement regimen.

As for your height goal, genetics plays a large role in determining height, so it is hard to say for sure if you will reach 5'9"-5'10". However, at 17 years old, you likely still have some growth potential left, so making sure you are getting adequate nutrition and taking care of your overall health is important for maximizing your height potential.

Regarding erectile dysfunction, it is not necessarily related to your testosterone levels. If your levels are consistently low, your doctor may consider treatment options such as HGH therapy, but this would require a detailed evaluation and discussion.

Regarding your torsion, it is unlikely to have an impact on your hormones. However, it is important to mention any past medical conditions or surgeries to your doctor so they have a complete picture of your health history.

instruction: Hi doctor,Five years ago my mother was diagnosed with fibromyalgia. I think she also has rheumatoid arthritis. For the past five years, she was managing the pain with anti-inflammatory medicine, Lyrica, Mythycobal, Voltaren injections, herbal creams, etc. You can see the veins in her hands popping out. I also realized that the pain has got worse now.For about 12 months the doctor put her only on Prednisolone 5 mg/day and painkiller when necessary. She was fine till last month but the pain increased in her hands now. In the daytime she is fine and the pain starts mildly in the evening. When she lies down in the bed she gets electrical tingling in her legs by which her sleep gets disturbed. She has undergone several tests last week and I attached them for your reference. She did not consult a rheumatologist yet. What medication can I give to reduce the inflammation and cure her? Her ESR, CPR, and ANA are quite high. The pain in her hands and the tingling in her legs at night are agonizing her life. Kindly provide your expert advice.
response:
Hello,

I am sorry to hear about your mother's condition. Based on the test results you provided, it does suggest that your mother has an autoimmune disorder such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus. It is important for her to consult a rheumatologist to confirm the diagnosis and to receive proper treatment.

In terms of medication, there are several options for reducing inflammation and managing pain. These include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), and biologic drugs. Prednisone is a type of steroid that can reduce inflammation, but it is not typically used as a long-term treatment due to its potential side effects.

DMARDs such as methotrexate and sulfasalazine can slow the progression of the disease and prevent joint damage. Biologic drugs such as Enbrel, Humira, and Remicade can also reduce inflammation and prevent joint damage.

In addition to medication, physical therapy and exercise can also help manage pain and improve joint flexibility. Your mother may also benefit from alternative therapies such as acupuncture, massage therapy, or cognitive behavioral therapy.

Overall, it is important for your mother to follow up with a rheumatologist to receive proper diagnosis and treatment.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have been given hepatitis B blood test that showed the HBsAg negative and the hepatitis B core antibody image as positive. I am currently getting labs done for hepatitis B Surf Ab Quant, HBsAg screen, hepatitis B virus profile, and panel. I am getting conflicting information on websites and from healthcare professionals that hepatitis B does not ever leave the body but I also read that 98 % of the people who get it cleared the disease from the body. My question is what is the real answer, can I beat the virus and remove it from my body completely leaving only anti-bodies?
response:
Hello,

It is true that most people who are infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) are able to clear the virus from their bodies without any long-term consequences. However, about 5-10% of people who get infected with HBV are unable to clear the virus and develop chronic hepatitis B infection. Chronic hepatitis B infection can lead to liver damage, cirrhosis, liver cancer, and other complications.

Based on your test results, you have evidence of past exposure to HBV, but your current test results are negative for HBsAg, which means that you do not have an active hepatitis B infection. The positive hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc) indicates that you have had a previous HBV infection, but it cannot determine whether the infection was acute or chronic.

If you develop HBsAg positivity in the future, it may indicate the presence of an active HBV infection. However, if you do not develop HBsAg positivity and your hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs) levels become detectable, it may indicate that you have cleared the infection and developed immunity.

In summary, the majority of people who are infected with HBV are able to clear the virus from their bodies without any long-term consequences. However, some people may develop chronic hepatitis B infection, which can lead to liver damage and other complications. Based on your current test results, you do not have an active hepatitis B infection, and further testing may help determine whether you have developed immunity against the virus.

instruction: Hello doctor,Just two days ago I found out I was about 1-2 weeks pregnant. And it has been about 4 1/2 weeks since my last menstrual period. I have been stressing out badly due to the fact I have been on Lorazepam 1 mg every night for anxiety and PD for the last 2 years as well as Percocet 10 mg as needed for back pain. I have been taking both of the medications during my pregnancy when I had no idea I was pregnant. Since finding out I have tried tapering on both medications. The Percocet is making me sweat and very agitated and when I tried to cut down on the Lorazepam I was shaking and almost hallucinating and delusion. I also tried not taking the Lorazepam at all and woke up crying, shaking and sweating. I want to be off both these medicines but I am worried more about the Lorazepam as it is a class D pregnancy drug. I have read about the terrible problems this causes for infants. I am so scared that I am considering abortion. I do not want to be a terrible mother before I even give birth. I have been having bad panic attacks over this and cannot seem to relax as the complications of these medicines are always on my mind. Any advice at all would be very much appreciated.
response:
I understand your concern regarding the medication use during pregnancy. However, it is not advisable to abruptly stop taking either of the medications without consulting your doctor. Sudden discontinuation of benzodiazepines can cause withdrawal symptoms and pose a risk to the developing fetus. Similarly, opioid use during pregnancy has been associated with complications such as preterm labor and neonatal abstinence syndrome.

It is important to work with your healthcare provider to develop a tapering plan that safely and gradually reduces your medication use while also managing your symptoms. Your doctor may consider switching you to a safer medication or non-pharmacological treatments for anxiety and pain management.

Abortion may not be necessary if a cautious approach is taken to manage medication use during pregnancy. It is important to remember that many women have healthy pregnancies while taking medications under the supervision of their healthcare providers.

I would recommend scheduling an appointment with your regular OBGYN as soon as possible to discuss your concerns and develop a safe and effective plan for managing your medications during pregnancy.

instruction: Hello doctor,I need to know about cardiac dysfunction. I was told it was found on venous Doppler looking at DVT. What all information can you tell me about the blood vessels having a pulse and it being a cardiac dysfunction? That is all I was left with until the cardiologist consult.
response:
Cardiac dysfunction refers to a condition in which the heart is not able to pump blood efficiently due to damage or disease. This can lead to problems in blood flow throughout the body, including the veins and arteries. When a venous Doppler test is performed for suspected deep vein thrombosis (DVT), it can sometimes reveal abnormalities in the blood flow caused by poor cardiac function.

Normally, blood vessels do not have a pulse as they are not capable of generating their own rhythmic contractions like the heart. However, blood flow in the veins and arteries can be affected by the pulsations of nearby arteries or the rhythmic contractions of the heart. This is why a venous Doppler test can provide some insight into the functioning of the heart.

Your cardiologist will be able to provide more information about the specific cardiac dysfunction that was found on your venous Doppler test and what it means for your overall health. They may order further tests or treatments to address the underlying issue and improve your blood flow.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 29 year old. My doctor said that I have an umbilical hernia.Either open surgery or laparoscopy, which would be the best? After which surgery, can I lift heavy weights?I am a sports person and a bodybuilder. Please suggest.

The choice of surgery (open surgery vs laparoscopy) depends on several factors such as the size of the hernia, its location, and the surgeon's experience. In general, laparoscopy is a less invasive technique, resulting in less pain, smaller scars, and quicker recovery times than open surgery.

If you undergo laparoscopic surgery for an umbilical hernia, you will likely be able to resume your normal activities more quickly than with open surgery. You may be able to lift weights after just a few weeks, but this depends on your doctor's advice and the type of weightlifting you plan to do. It is important to follow your surgeon's instructions carefully to ensure a safe and successful recovery.

It is also important to note that if you continue to lift heavy weights frequently, you may be at a higher risk of developing a hernia in the future. Therefore, it may be helpful to modify your workout routine to minimize the risk of recurrence or new hernias.

Flecainide is an anti-arrhythmic medication that can help control palpitations and other abnormal heart rhythms associated with WPW. However, as you mentioned, there is a risk of creating more dangerous rhythms in some patients. Therefore, it is essential to monitor the heart rhythm with continuous electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring while taking Flecainide.

The decision to take Flecainide or any medication prior to ablation should be made based on the individual patient's risk-benefit analysis and discussed with your treating physician. The EP who prescribed the medication might have first-hand information about your condition and deemed it necessary to prescribe.

Additionally, a Flecainide overdose can cause adverse side effects, including palpitations, which limits its use to strictly clinical settings where there is constant monitoring of patients' conditions.

It is crucial to have a follow-up with your treating physician to monitor your heart rhythm on the medication and adjust the dosage as needed to avoid significant risk of developing more dangerous rhythms. 

Please note that if you have any side effects or palpitations, you should seek immediate medical attention.

Best regards.

instruction: Hi doctor,My daughter had braces for four years but her midline is off and she has a gummy smile. Her bite is fine but her teeth are not properly aligned and she does not have bone on her left side. Her orthodontist referred her to a maxillofacial surgeon who says she needs her upper jaw broken and rotated clockwise and slightly up to compensate for the lack of bone and her bottom jaw also has to be broken and rotated clockwise. It would all then be held by plates and screws. My biggest concern is that she is a beautiful girl and he says that her face will not change at all. Is that true with this kind of procedure?
response:
Hello! Based on what you have described, it sounds like your daughter may have a skeletal malocclusion, which means that her jaw bones are not properly positioned relative to each other. In some cases, this can lead to a gummy smile, an asymmetrical midline, and other aesthetic concerns.

Braces can correct some dental issues, but when the underlying problem is a skeletal discrepancy, orthognathic surgery (jaw surgery) may be necessary to achieve optimal results. In this case, the surgeon's recommendation to break and rotate the upper and lower jaw bones in order to correct the lack of bone and achieve proper alignment and balance between the jaws seems appropriate.

Regarding your concerns about changes in your daughter's facial appearance, it's important to note that orthognathic surgery is typically performed with the goal of achieving a harmonious, balanced facial profile. While it is possible that her facial appearance may change slightly as a result of the surgery, the changes should be proportional and subtle. Additionally, any aesthetic concerns that existed prior to the surgery - such as a gummy smile or asymmetrical midline - should be greatly improved if not completely corrected by the surgery itself.

That being said, I would encourage you and your daughter to have a thorough consultation with the surgeon to discuss the details of the proposed surgery, including any potential risks, benefits, and realistic expectations for the outcome. It's important to have a clear understanding of the procedure and its potential impact on your daughter's facial appearance before making a decision about whether to move forward with the surgery.

Although your most recent blood test showed normal thyroid results, it is important to note that thyroid hormone levels can fluctuate, which could explain your ongoing symptoms. If you are trying to conceive, it is important to make sure your thyroid levels are well-controlled before becoming pregnant. Untreated or poorly controlled hyperthyroidism during pregnancy can increase the risk of complications such as premature birth, low birth weight, and preeclampsia.

I would recommend consulting with an endocrinologist to further evaluate and manage your thyroid condition. They can perform additional tests to assess your thyroid function and determine whether additional treatment, such as medication or radioactive iodine therapy, may be necessary.

In summary, although fluctuations in thyroid hormone levels are common in hyperthyroidism, untreated or poorly controlled hyperthyroidism during pregnancy can have serious consequences. Therefore, it is important to have your thyroid levels well-controlled before becoming pregnant and to seek the guidance of an endocrinologist.

instruction: Hello doctor,What is HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) and what is the maximum possible impact of this disease in future on a person? Can this disease make one blind?
response:
Hereditary macular degeneration (HMD) is an inherited eye disorder that affects the macula, which is the central part of the retina responsible for sharp and detailed vision. HMD is characterized by progressive damage to the macula over time, leading to a gradual loss of central vision.

The impact of HMD on a person's vision can vary depending on the severity of the disease. In some cases, HMD may cause only mild vision problems that can be managed with corrective lenses or low vision aids. However, as the disease progresses, it can lead to significant vision loss and even legal blindness in some cases.

While HMD can cause significant visual impairment, it does not typically result in complete blindness as other parts of the retina outside the macula are still functional, allowing for peripheral vision. However, it is important to note that the impact of HMD on a person's vision can be unpredictable and dependent on individual factors. 

If you have concerns about HMD or any other vision problems, it is recommended to consult an eye doctor or ophthalmologist for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

In general, the goal of thyroid hormone replacement therapy is to achieve normal levels of thyroid hormones in the body. While natural desiccated thyroid hormone medications (such as Armour and Nature-thyroid) contain both T4 and T3 hormones, synthetic thyroid hormone medications (such as levothyroxine and liothyronine) can also be used in combination as well. I recommend consulting with an endocrinologist or other qualified healthcare provider who can evaluate your complete medical history, perform thorough laboratory tests, and recommend the most appropriate thyroid hormone replacement therapy for you. instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 46-year-old male. A month ago, I had a heart stroke and underwent angio for blood clotting thrombus. My CBC report at that time shows a platelet count at 24 lakhs. I received CALR Exon 9 mutation analysis report today. It reads \"CALR Exon 9 mutation is detected by PCR amplification of Exon 9 of CALR, followed by sequencing of coding and junctional region of the Exon. The sequence is compared with the reference sequence NM-004343 for the analysis of mutations.\" Hematologist prescribed me Anagrelide 0.5 mg. Do I have to worry? Can it be cured by medication?
response:
Based on the information you have provided, it seems like you have been diagnosed with a myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) called essential thrombocythemia (ET). This condition is characterized by an overproduction of platelets in the bone marrow, which can increase the risk of blood clots like the one you experienced. The CALR gene mutation is commonly found in patients with ET and can help confirm the diagnosis.

Anagrelide is a medication that can help reduce the number of platelets in the blood and lower the risk of blood clots. It is often prescribed for patients with ET. However, it is important to follow your hematologist's instructions and monitor your platelet count regularly. In some cases, additional treatments may be necessary to manage the condition.

While there is currently no cure for ET, with proper management it can be controlled and the risk of complications can be reduced. It is essential to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a healthy diet, and not smoking. Additionally, it is important to work closely with your healthcare team to manage your condition and prevent future complications.

instruction: Hi doctor,My scar revision surgery is not healing well, and it seems worse than last week. Please see the attached picture. I cannot tell if it is this or the creasing making it worse. I am starting to get very depressed about this scar revision. It was bad enough getting mugged and getting this wound. Now it is not healing even after a scar revision surgery. Thanks.
response:
Hello,

I am sorry to hear that your scar revision surgery is not healing well. Based on the picture you have attached, it does seem like the scar is red and raised, which indicates that it is still in the early stages of healing. Involuntary frowning can definitely contribute to the worsening of the scar, as repeated facial movements can cause tension on the incision site and slow down the healing process. Taping your forehead so that you cannot make frown lines may be helpful, as it can decrease tension on the scar.

Botox can also be effective in temporarily stopping frowning and reducing tension on the incision site, but it is important to discuss this with your surgeon before proceeding. Your surgeon can also recommend other scar management techniques, such as massage, pressure garments or laser therapy, that may be beneficial for your specific case.

Using a vitamin C and silicone scar cream is a good start, but it is important to make sure that you are using it correctly and not over-applying it. Over-applying scar creams can cause more harm than good, as it can increase the risk of infection and interfere with the healing process. You can ask your surgeon or a wound care nurse for advice on how much and how often to apply the scar cream.

It is normal to feel depressed and frustrated about the scar revision, but it is important to stay positive and patient. Scar healing is a slow process, and it can take weeks or even months for the scar to fully heal and fade. instruction: Hi doctor,My mother has a lump on her breast. She underwent a biopsy. In the biopsy report, it came as benign. Another test showed that she has stage 3 breast cancer (she has no symptoms) and the doctor advised us for a mastectomy. The doctor recommended us to do some tests such as blood count, breast X-ray, and ultrasound. The results came normal (there is no mass lesion present, and there is no metastasis seen). Is there any confirmatory test available to find breast cancer?
response:
Yes, there are confirmatory tests available to diagnose breast cancer. After a diagnosis of breast cancer is made, a staging workup is done to determine the extent of the disease. This may include imaging tests such as a CT (computed tomography) or PET (positron emission tomography) scan to look for metastasis to other organs.

Once the cancer has been staged, further tests may be done to determine the specific type of breast cancer and to identify whether certain genes or proteins are present. These tests can help guide treatment decisions and provide important prognostic information.

In some cases, a second opinion from a different specialist may also be helpful in confirming the diagnosis and determining the most appropriate treatment plan for your mother. It is important to discuss all of these options with your mother's healthcare team, and to ask any questions you may have.

When I try to focus on an image, I have severe diplopia. The diplopia disappears when I try to correct the squint. At present, I am doing higher studies and the diplopia is really bothering me. Will doing a squint surgery be of any use? Is there anything that I can try?
response:
Hello. Based on your history and symptoms, it seems like you have exotropia with diplopia in your right eye. The deviation of your eye may be the result of the macular injury you suffered 10 years ago. As your diplopia is significantly bothering you and affecting your studies, squint surgery may be considered as an option to correct the misalignment of your eye.

However, before any surgery is recommended, a complete eye examination is required, including an assessment of the visual functions of both eyes and the degree of squint. Squint surgery may help to correct the outward deviation of the eye but may not necessarily resolve the diplopia completely. Other options include prism glasses, which are designed to correct the diplopia by changing the direction of the light entering your eye. Prism glasses are preferred when there is a small deviation or when the degree of deviation is variable.

In summary, squint surgery may be an option for you if it is determined to be appropriate after a thorough assessment of your ocular health and visual functions. You can discuss these options with your ophthalmologist for further guidance.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have a lower wisdom tooth that has been infected chronically for well over a year. I also have an upper molar that is broken decayed and has been like this for years. She slightly cleaned the gums around the wisdom tooth and prescribed me Cephalexin and sent me on my way. I have been taking Cephalexin for a few days, and yet the tooth is still oozing. My throat is red and irritated, the gums inflamed and there is no swelling in the mouth. Also, my nostril on that side is tender and painful. The dentist had said the next thing she could give me was Clindamycin, but I have a fear of the side effects of that medicine. I already have heart problems and mild stomach issues. I understand your concerns about potential side effects of these antibiotics. While they can have side effects, it's important to balance the risks and benefits of taking them. Untreated dental infections can lead to serious complications, including the spread of infection to other parts of the body. Your healthcare provider will likely consider your medical history and current health status when deciding which antibiotic to prescribe. 

In the meantime, you can try to alleviate your symptoms by gently rinsing your mouth with warm salt water and taking over-the-counter pain relievers (if you are able to take them). You should also focus on maintaining good oral hygiene, including brushing twice a day and flossing daily. 

If you are experiencing severe symptoms or are worried about the progression of your infection, I strongly recommend contacting your healthcare provider or seeking emergency medical attention. 

Take care!

My mom experienced severe pain after this incident when she was rushed to an Ophthalmologist. The doctor had no clue about the reason for her eye pop out. response:
I am sorry to hear about your mother's condition. It sounds like she may be experiencing a condition called proptosis or bulging eyes, which can be a symptom of various underlying medical conditions, including thyroid eye disease.

In some cases, proptosis may cause the eye to become displaced, and in rare situations, the eye may pop out of its socket. This is known as globe luxation, and it is a medical emergency.

While waiting for the results of your mother's medical tests, it is important to keep a close watch on her symptoms and seek medical attention immediately if she experiences any sudden changes in her vision or severe eye pain. In the meantime, your mother may benefit from eye lubricants to reduce eye irritation, and she may need to avoid activities that cause eye strain or pressure, such as heavy lifting or bending over.

Treatment for proptosis depends on the underlying cause, and it may include medication, surgery, or a combination of both. I would recommend that your mother undergo a comprehensive eye exam and consultation with an ophthalmologist or an eye specialist for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.
