instruction: Hello doctor,I am having a premature ejaculation problem. I got married five months back. Initially two months back, I was able to do intercourse well but now before the start of the intercourse, I am getting the ejaculation. We are planning for a child now but I am much worried. My height is 187 cm and weight is 102 kg.
response:
Premature ejaculation is a common sexual problem faced by many men. In most cases, it can be effectively treated.

There are several factors that can contribute to premature ejaculation, such as performance anxiety, stress, depression, biological factors, and relationship issues. It is important to identify the underlying cause in order to address the problem effectively.

In terms of lifestyle changes, losing weight and improving overall physical fitness can be beneficial for improving sexual health. It is also important to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly.

Behavioral therapy, such as the stop-start technique or the squeeze technique, can help delay ejaculation during intercourse. Medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or topical anesthetics can also be prescribed by a doctor.

It is important to have an open and honest conversation with your partner about your concerns and work together as a team to find a solution. A sexual therapist or counselor can also be helpful in addressing underlying psychological factors and improving communication between partners.

Overall, premature ejaculation is a treatable condition and with the right approach, you can overcome the problem and achieve a fulfilling sexual relationship with your partner.

It is recommended that you continue to monitor your symptoms and get retested for HIV at least 4 weeks after the exposure to ensure accurate results. It is important to complete the full course of antibiotics as prescribed by your urologist and also drink plenty of fluids to help flush out the bacteria from your urinary system. Once the infection is treated, the pain in the scrotum should also subside.

To prevent recurrent UTIs, you should maintain good hygiene, drink plenty of water, urinate frequently, and avoid holding urine for prolonged periods. Also, practice safe sex and use condoms to prevent STIs. If you have any concerns or doubts about your sexual health, you can get tested for STIs at a laboratory or clinic.

In summary, based on your symptoms and urine culture report, it is essential to complete the course of antibiotics prescribed by your urologist to treat the current UTI. It is also important to take preventive measures to avoid future infections.

instruction: Hello doctor,My foreskin of the penis is tight. Is there any problem in the future during sex? My age is 20 years, male, and single.

Phimosis can lead to difficulties during sex such as pain, discomfort, or even tears in the foreskin. It can also increase the risk of developing infections or inflammation.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have minor beta thalassemia which I got from my mother, but unlike her (asymptomatic), I have anemia symptoms like paleness, shortness of breath after the least effort, feeling tired all the time, broken nails and I want to know if it could be due to lack of iron? Could people with minor beta thalassemia also get iron deficiency anemia? Knowing that I get heavy cycles and my diet is very poor.
response:
Hello,

Yes, iron deficiency anemia can occur in people with minor beta thalassemia. Beta thalassemia is a genetic condition that can affect the production of hemoglobin, which is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. As a result, people with beta thalassemia may experience anemia, which is a condition in which the body does not have enough red blood cells or hemoglobin to function properly.

Iron deficiency anemia occurs when the body does not have enough iron to produce hemoglobin. This can happen if a person's diet is poor in iron, or if they have heavy menstrual cycles, gastrointestinal bleeding, or other medical conditions that cause blood loss.

In your case, it is possible that your anemia symptoms are due to iron deficiency, especially given your heavy menstrual cycles and poor diet. However, it is also possible that your symptoms are related to your beta thalassemia.

It would be a good idea to speak with your doctor about your symptoms and have a blood test to determine if you are iron deficient. Your doctor may also recommend dietary changes, iron supplements, or other treatments to help manage your symptoms and prevent further complications.

I hope this helps. Let me know if you have any other questions!

instruction: Hello doctor, Me and my fiance had sex and seems out of fear took Ipill because it was unprotected for sometime so many doubts in mind but no leakage or injection of sperm, etc. Three time UPT done but all negative. Hello! As an AI language model, I cannot provide medical advice or diagnose conditions. However, I can provide you with general information.

The pill contains a high dose of hormones that can affect the normal menstrual cycle, causing changes in the timing and duration of your periods. Delayed or irregular periods are not uncommon after taking the i-pill. 

However, if your period is significantly delayed or you have other symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, or dizziness, it may be a good idea to visit a doctor for a check-up. A doctor can perform a pregnancy test and evaluate any potential underlying causes for the missed period. 

It's important to remember that emergency contraception such as the i-pill is not a reliable form of birth control and should be used sparingly. If you are sexually active and do not wish to become pregnant, you should consider using a regular method of contraception such as barrier methods (e.g. condoms), hormonal methods (e.g. birth control pills), or more long-term options like intrauterine devices (IUDs). A doctor can provide more information about the available options and help you choose the best one for your needs.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am of 21 and I am suffering from permanent blurry eye vision in my only right one. It is by birth. Is there any chance to cure it without any permanent glasses and without any operations. Suggest me, please.

How do I tell, if these are pregnancy symptoms or if it is because of the Depo shot? I did miss my last shot three months ago. Last month I took a home pregnancy test it came back negative. instruction: Hello doctor,I had stomach pain after which my report was confirmed as gallbladder stones. What is the further procedure? Please let me know all the details, including the cost.
response:
Hello!

Gallbladder stones are a common condition that can cause inflammation, pain, and other symptoms. The treatment for gallbladder stones depends on a few factors, including the size and number of stones, and the severity of symptoms.

In most cases, the recommended treatment is surgery to remove the gallbladder. This is called a cholecystectomy, and it can be done through open surgery or laparoscopic surgery (also known as keyhole surgery).

Laparoscopic surgery is a minimally invasive approach that involves making small incisions in the abdomen and using a special tool to remove the gallbladder. This is less invasive than open surgery and typically has a faster recovery time. The cost of laparoscopic surgery can vary depending on the hospital and location, but it can range from $3000 to $10000.

Before surgery, your doctor may recommend a special diet to help manage symptoms and prevent complications. They may also prescribe medication to help dissolve small gallstones, although this treatment is typically only effective for certain types of stones.

After surgery, most people can return to regular activities within a few weeks. Your doctor will provide specific instructions for recovery and follow-up care.

It is important to discuss all treatment options and cost with your doctor before making a decision. Other treatment options for gallbladder stones can include medications or shock wave therapy, but these may not be appropriate for everyone. I hope this information helps!

instruction: Hello doctor,My 24 days newborn son is suffering from midgut malrotation. Is this a problem?
response:
Midgut malrotation is a condition in which the intestines do not develop properly during fetal development. It can cause a variety of symptoms and complications, such as abdominal pain, vomiting, and bowel obstruction. In severe cases, it can also lead to intestinal necrosis, which is a medical emergency.

If your newborn son has been diagnosed with midgut malrotation, it is important to consult with a pediatric surgeon immediately. Surgery may be necessary to correct the condition and prevent further complications.

It is also important to closely monitor your son's symptoms and follow your doctor's advice for care and management. With proper treatment and monitoring, many children with midgut malrotation go on to lead healthy, normal lives.

instruction: Hello doctor,Obstructive jaundice has been detected. ERCP was done. Serum bilirubin still very high. MRCP report says everything is alright but neither serum bilirubin nor yellowness has got less.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your condition. Obstructive jaundice occurs when bile flow from the liver to the intestines is blocked, causing the buildup of bilirubin in the blood and subsequent yellowing of the skin and eyes.

ERCP is a procedure that uses a long, flexible tube with a camera and tools to remove the obstruction and improve bile flow. However, if your serum bilirubin levels remain high despite this procedure and MRCP report showing normal results, there may be other underlying causes contributing to the obstruction or damage to the liver.

It's important to follow up with your doctor or gastroenterologist for further evaluation, as high levels of bilirubin can lead to complications such as liver damage or failure if left untreated. They may recommend additional tests such as a liver function test or a liver biopsy to determine the underlying cause of your condition and recommend appropriate treatment options.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 61 year old female and a diabetic for the last ten years. I had a cystocele repair surgery along with hysterectomy and cervix and ovaries removal five months ago. Please let me know if this is serious and whether I have to take a course of antibiotics for it. I do not have any symptoms of UTI or abscess etc. Also, the cystocele repair was not a success as the bladder is still at the mouth of the vagina. Please also let me know if anything can be done to put the bladder back in place. If this is not done, what are the repercussions?
response:
Hello! Thank you for reaching out.

Enterococcus faecalis is a bacteria that naturally occurs in the gut and is usually harmless. However, it can cause infections in the urinary tract or bloodstream in certain situations, such as after surgery. In your case, since you don't have any symptoms of UTI or abscess, it's possible that the presence of Enterococcus faecalis is just a colonizer of your urinary tract and not causing any infection. This could be monitored closely and may not require antibiotics.

Regarding your cystocele repair, it's unfortunate that the surgery did not provide the desired outcome. If the bladder is still at the mouth of the vagina, this could lead to urinary incontinence or recurring UTIs due to the urine being trapped in the bladder. In some cases, a repeat surgery may be necessary to reposition the bladder. However, this can be a complicated procedure and requires careful evaluation by a specialist who specializes in pelvic floor surgery.

I would suggest consulting your surgeon or a urologist with expertise in pelvic floor disorders to discuss your options for further management.

I hope this helps!

instruction: Hi doctor,I have been with the same partner for 8 years now. During these all 8 years I have had several UTIs with some leading to severe kidney infections. Unfortunately two days later, the symptoms came back (please note that I had sex with my partner the day before) with burning sensation when urinating and painful when standing with the need to go toilet every 2 to 3 minutes. I went back to the clinic the same day to get it checked and take more antibiotics.But to my surprise, the urine test came back clear for UTI, and my symptoms disappeared. Then the doctor advised me to get tested for Chlamydia as the symptoms can sometimes be mistaken to be UTI. I have been diagnosed with Chlamydia at the beginning of this same relationship and was treated for it. My partner was also tested, but his results came back negative. Is it possible that the treatment that I had for Chlamydia 8 years ago did not clear it entirely and this lead to several UTIs and kidney infections? And also, would the antibiotics for UTI clear Chlamydia? Thank you in advance for your help.
response:
Hello! It is possible for untreated or inadequately treated Chlamydia to lead to recurrent UTIs and kidney infections over time. However, it is also possible for your symptoms to be caused by a UTI despite negative urine tests. This may happen if the urine sample was not collected properly or if the bacteria causing the infection are not in high enough numbers to be detected by the test. 

Regarding your question about antibiotics for UTI clearing Chlamydia, the answer is no. Nitrofurantoin, which is commonly used to treat UTIs, does not effectively treat Chlamydia. If you do have Chlamydia, you will need a different type of antibiotic. 

It's important that you follow up with further testing for Chlamydia and that your partner is also tested, even if his previous test came back negative. It's possible that he was infected with Chlamydia since his last negative test, as it can be asymptomatic in men, or he may have been infected by a different partner if he has had any. If you or your partner are found to have Chlamydia, both of you will need to take antibiotics to treat the infection, even if you are not currently experiencing symptoms. 

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 42 years old and have been diagnosed with multiple uterine fibroids. Two of them are a little more than 3 cm at different places in the uterus. In the past, I have been operated for endometriosis level 4. As usual, the gynecologist is suggesting a hysterectomy. But since I am in my perimenopausal phase, can the fibroids shrink with medication? I have been suggested Fibroease.
response:
Hello,

Uterine fibroids are non-cancerous growths that can develop in or on the uterus. Fibroids are usually benign, but they can cause bothersome symptoms, such as heavy or painful periods, abdominal bloating, and pain during intercourse.

Treatment options typically depend on the location and size of the fibroids, as well as the patient's symptoms and future reproductive plans. Medications like Fibroease may be helpful in managing symptoms, but they are not known to significantly reduce the size of uterine fibroids.

Hormonal treatment options, such as birth control pills, may provide temporary relief, but they may not be suitable for women who have had endometriosis in the past. Surgical options range from minimally invasive procedures, like uterine artery embolization, to more invasive options, like hysterectomy. Your gynecologist can help you determine the best treatment option for your situation.

It is also important to note that menopause may naturally shrink fibroids due to the decrease in hormone production. However, it is difficult to predict how long this may take and if it will provide sufficient relief from symptoms.

I hope this information helps. Please discuss your options further with your gynecologist to determine the best course of action.

Three days later, I started experiencing nausea, soreness of the breasts, lower back as well as abdominal pain, frequent urination, and tiredness. This carried on for almost a week. I then noticed a light brown discharge. And, from the next day, I bled for six days. I usually bleed for seven days. After my periods, I still had the symptoms.Nearly a month later, I got my periods again, but on the first day I had severe cramps and used a tampon. On the third day, there was a slight discharge which was brown in color. On the fourth day, there was some bleeding, but not at night. Today would be day five, and I still do not see blood. My main concern is that my vagina feels different. It is more firm than usual and feels tight. I sometimes feel a pulling sensation. Could it be due to the morning-after pills? I did home pregnancy tests, and it came back negative. It has been a month and 18 days now, since the intercourse.
response:
Hello! It's unlikely that the morning-after pills are causing your current symptoms. The main side effects of the morning-after pill are nausea, vomiting, headache, and fatigue, but they usually resolve within a few days. The symptoms you describe could be related to hormonal changes or a different underlying condition. 

The brown discharge and light bleeding you experienced could have been implantation bleeding, but since you had a negative pregnancy test, it's more likely to be related to hormonal changes. The feeling of tightness and pulling sensation could be related to inflammation or infection in the genital area. I would recommend visiting your gynecologist for an evaluation to rule out any underlying conditions such as vaginitis, bacterial vaginosis, or a urinary tract infection. 

If your symptoms persist or worsen, or if you develop new symptoms such as fever or chills, it's important to seek medical attention right away. In the meantime, you can try taking over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to relieve cramps and discomfort. Ensure that you practice safe sex to prevent unwanted pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 29-year-old female. I was just diagnosed with chronic urticaria. I went to an allergic specialist for skin testing because my skin was so sensitive I reacted to everything. They then did the RAST test on me. Everything came out class 0 except for egg white, wheat, and oats being class 2 and milk, and hazelnut being class 1. Can these cause anaphylaxis? How accurate are the RAST test? I was put on an elimination diet but the hives are still there. I occasionally get angioedema with it also. Can angiodema cause anaphylaxis? As you can see I am so scared for my throat to close up that I am scared to eat anything. I have only been eating a couple of things daily and live off that.
response:
Hello,

I'm sorry to hear about your condition. Chronic urticaria can be an extremely frustrating and uncomfortable condition to live with. I'll try to answer your questions to the best of my knowledge.

Firstly, the RAST test is generally considered to be a reliable test for detecting IgE-mediated allergies. It measures the amount of IgE antibodies in your blood to specific allergens. However, it isn't 100% accurate and can still give false positive or false negative results. So, it's not uncommon to have positive RAST test results but not have any symptoms upon exposure to the allergens.

Regarding the potential for anaphylaxis, a positive RAST test doesn't necessarily mean that you will experience anaphylaxis upon exposure to a particular allergen. Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can affect multiple organs in the body, including the airways, cardiovascular system, and skin. Not everyone who has a positive allergy test will experience anaphylaxis. However, it is possible to have an anaphylactic reaction to any allergen, not just the ones you tested positive for.

Angioedema is a condition in which there is a rapid swelling of the deeper layers of the skin and tissue beneath. It can occur in response to an allergic reaction, but it can also be caused by other factors, such as certain medications or underlying medical conditions. While angioedema isn't typically associated with anaphylaxis, it can cause swelling in the throat, which can potentially lead to difficulty breathing.

It's understandable to be afraid of eating due to the possibility of an allergic reaction. However, it's important to have a well-balanced and varied diet to ensure that your body is getting all the nutrients it needs to function properly. You may want to consider working with a registered dietitian or nutritionist who can help you develop a safe and balanced meal plan that takes your food allergies into account.

I hope this helps. If you have any further concerns, I encourage you to speak with your doctor or allergist.

instruction: Hello doctor,Since the last 10 months, my periods are very irregular. I get periods only once every three to four months. I am on treatment for abdominal TB since the last one and a half years. I take Sompraz D20 on an empty stomach in the morning. I take Duonase nasal spray (two puffs in each nostril) twice a day. I take Immunace Forte after lunch and Libotryp at bedtime. So, why are my periods not regular? Is this a side effect of my medicine or could it be due to a disease? Recently, I was also prescribed Uprise-D3 (60000) once a month for six months. My recent 25-OH vitamin D total is 21.1 ng/mL. I also have sudden weight gain. My weight in the last one and a half years increased from 57 kg to 81 kg. I also have a chronic nose block.
response:
Irregular periods can have a variety of causes including stress, hormonal imbalances, ovarian cysts, thyroid disorders, and certain medications. It is possible that the medications you are taking for abdominal TB and your nasal issue could be contributing to your irregular periods, but it is difficult to say for sure without a full evaluation.

Your sudden weight gain and chronic nose block may also be related to your medical condition and/or medications. I recommend discussing these concerns with your doctor to determine if any adjustments to your treatment plan are necessary.

It is also important to mention that low vitamin D levels can contribute to a variety of health issues, including irregular periods and weight gain. Continuing to take Uprise-D3 and monitoring your vitamin D levels with regular blood tests is a good step towards improving your overall health.

instruction: Hi doctor,I had a history of thyroid issue before pregnancy. Currently, I have an issue of hair fall and mild body aches.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have a generic query. Can we trust the NABL and CAP accreditation laboratories in terms of reliability and accuracy? And what does they mean? And all NABL and CAP labs are of same quality? Please explain in detail.
response:
NABL (National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories) and CAP (College of American Pathologists) are both accrediting bodies that assess the quality and reliability of laboratories. Accreditation is a voluntary process, where laboratories undergo rigorous evaluation based on international standards to demonstrate their ability to provide accurate and reliable results.

The accreditation of a laboratory by NABL or CAP means that it has successfully passed the assessment process and has met the required standards for quality, accuracy, and reliability. The accreditation demonstrates that the laboratory is technically competent to carry out specific tests and provide accurate and reliable results.

However, not all NABL and CAP accredited labs are of the same quality. While accreditation provides a certain level of assurance, the quality of laboratory testing depends on various factors such as competence of laboratory personnel, quality of equipment and reagents used, and the overall management of the laboratory.

Therefore, it is necessary to choose an accredited laboratory with a good reputation and proven track record of accurate and reliable results. It is also important to understand the scope of accreditation of the laboratory and whether it covers the specific tests you require.

In summary, NABL and CAP are trusted accrediting bodies that ensure the quality and reliability of laboratory testing. However, it is essential to choose a laboratory that has a good reputation and proven track record of accuracy and reliability, and whose scope of accreditation covers the specific tests required.

instruction: Hello doctor,How eating habits or certain foods impact sleep? How much should men be stretching at 25, 30, 35, 40, 45? Does the need to be flexible vary by age?
response:
Hello! Thank you for your questions!

1. Eating habits and certain foods can impact sleep in various ways. Heavy meals close to bedtime can cause indigestion and discomfort, making it difficult to fall asleep. Foods that are high in sugar, caffeine or spicy foods can also interfere with sleep quality. On the other hand, consuming foods that are high in tryptophan (a natural sleep aid) such as milk, turkey, and nuts, can promote a better night's rest. Additionally, eating foods with high levels of antioxidants, such as fruits and vegetables, have been shown to improve sleep quality. It's best to avoid consuming heavy, sugary, or spicy foods a few hours before bed.

2. Stretching needs can vary depending on factors such as activity level, lifestyle, and past injuries. There is no set routine for stretching that works for everyone. However, stretching regularly can improve flexibility, improve range of motion, and decrease the risk of injury.

  * At age 25, men generally have a better range of motion and flexibility. However, stretching can still help maintain this level of flexibility and prevent injuries.
  * At age 30, men may start to notice some decrease in flexibility due to the natural aging process. Stretching can help prevent stiffness and injury.
  * At age 35, men may start to notice some limitations in their range of motion, especially if they have a sedentary lifestyle. Stretching can help improve flexibility and overall physical function.
  * At age 40, men may start to experience more stiffness and soreness due to decreasing flexibility. Regular stretching can help prevent injuries and maintain activity levels.
  * At age 45, men may notice further decreases in flexibility and range of motion due to aging. Regular stretching can help reduce these limitations and improve function.

Overall, the need to be flexible may vary by age, but it's important to maintain a regular stretching routine throughout adulthood to maintain mobility and reduce the risk of injury.

instruction: Hello doctor,My baby is 10 months old, and he is two months premature. If I feed him with solid food, he does vomiting. Is it not safe for him to feed with solid food?
response:
Hello! It's understandable to be concerned about feeding your premature baby solid food. At 10 months old, most babies are ready to start taking solid foods, but some babies may need a little more time to develop the necessary skills to eat solid foods without difficulty.

If your baby is vomiting when you feed him solid food, it may be that he is not yet ready for solid food. Sometimes, babies need more time to develop the necessary chewing and swallowing skills required to take solid foods. You may want to delay introducing solid foods for a little while longer.

In the meantime, continue to breastfeed or bottle-feed your baby as usual. You can also introduce pureed food to your baby by making a soft and smooth puree of vegetables or fruits. If your baby is still having trouble with solid food, consult your pediatrician or a feeding specialist for further evaluation and guidance. They can give you more specific advice and help you determine if your baby is ready for solid food.

While it may take some time, it's certainly possible to regain normal function with proper treatment and care. Keep working with your healthcare team and following their recommendations to give yourself the best chance for recovery.

instruction: Hello doctor,I will be facing major surgery for stage three lung cancer contained in the left lobe. I am extremely allergic to Fentanyl, Propofol, and Versed. Are there any alternatives to these anesthetics? I am currently on Synthroid.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis of stage three lung cancer. It is good to hear that you are alert about potential anesthetic allergies, and it's important for your anesthesiologist to be aware of them as well.

There are several alternative anesthetics available that can be used instead of Fentanyl, Propofol, and Versed. Your anesthesiologist may use a combination of medications to achieve deep anesthesia during your surgery. For example, they may use medications such as lidocaine, ketamine, or dexmedetomidine. Additionally, regional anesthesia techniques such as epidural anesthesia or peripheral nerve blocks may be used.

It is also important to inform your care team about your Synthroid (levothyroxine) use. Your thyroid function levels will need to be closely monitored before and after surgery to ensure that your medication is still effective.

Lastly, it is essential to have a frank and open conversation with your anesthesiologist about your allergies and any concerns you might have about undergoing anesthesia. They will work with you to develop a safe and effective anesthesia plan tailored to your individual needs.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have rheumatoid arthritis. There is a long waiting list to see a rheumatologist in my place. I am thinking of seeing a private doctor but I have limited funds. How often would I need to see a rheumatologist? I cannot afford it every week or maybe every few months. How often do you think I need a doctor visit? I am hoping to be prescribed a DMARD like Methotrexate. Then when my slot comes up with the NHS I will go there.I take Naproxen which is not enough and I had a cortisone injection in my knee a couple of months ago. The swelling did not go down completely but I walked better. It has worn off now, and I have pain in more joints and a feeling of lumps under my feet. I am on a special diet and my CRP, ESR and high rheumatoid factor have gone down by half. But lately, I feel unwell. I would like to know the frequency of visits needed.
response:
Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your rheumatoid arthritis. In general, patients with rheumatoid arthritis should see a rheumatologist every three to six months for follow-up visits. However, the frequency of visits may vary depending on the severity of symptoms and the effectiveness of treatment.

Since you are experiencing unwellness and increasing joint pain, it is important to see a rheumatologist as soon as possible to adjust your treatment plan. If you cannot afford frequent visits to a private doctor, consider discussing a payment plan or reduced rates with the doctor's office. It is also helpful to communicate your financial concerns with the doctor and see if they can suggest any alternative options.

As for medication, Methotrexate is commonly prescribed as a DMARD for rheumatoid arthritis. However, dosing and monitoring require close medical supervision, so it is important to see a rheumatologist for medication management.

Continue to follow your special diet and monitor your CRP, ESR, and rheumatoid factor. It's great that you have seen improvement, but it's important to address any new symptoms with a healthcare provider. I hope this information helps, and I wish you the best with your treatment.

instruction: Hello doctor,Due to the use of Skinlite, I have sunburn on my face and now it looks like the dark spot. But I am using Kojivit gel for a dark spot. Is Kojivit gel good for the dark spot?

instruction: Hello doctor,My wife and I had some argument about my past. I had lied to her about the number of sex partners I had. That hurts her because she explained that her perception of me was built on the fact that she knew that I only had a few sex partners.We have been discussing this for months, but now after having these discussions and arguments, I realize that when we are to have sex, I get anxious. I will get an erection, but when its time to enter, it falls. I want to know, how to get my mind to a place of not over thinking so that I am not distracted. Kindly help.
response:
I understand that this situation can be distressing for you and your wife. It's important to realize that anxiety and stress can negatively affect sexual function. The first step is to work on improving communication and building trust between you and your wife. It's okay to have past experiences, but it's important to be honest about them to avoid hurting your partner's trust.

You mentioned that you feel anxious about sex. This could be due to guilt or shame about lying to your wife or feeling like you have to perform well. Try to identify your triggers and work on addressing them. You can talk to your wife about your anxiety and find ways to make each other feel comfortable and safe.

In addition, practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, mindfulness, or meditation before engaging in sexual activity. These techniques can help you calm your mind and focus on the present moment.

It may also be helpful to speak to a therapist who can help you work through your anxiety and address any underlying issues that may be contributing to your sexual difficulties.

Overall, building trust and open communication with your partner and learning to manage your anxiety through relaxation techniques and therapy can help you overcome this issue and improve your sexual function.

instruction: Hi doctor,I feel a strange glitch in my vision. It is quite big and takes up a large portion of my central vision. It is neither a shadow nor a flash, it looks like a greasy fingerprint smudge in my vision which disappears quickly. It happens when I blink, but mostly occurs when my eyes move quickly. I have had it for the past few days and I do not know if it is anything to be concerned about. Please help.
response: Hello! I'm sorry to hear about your symptoms. Based on your description, it sounds like you may be experiencing a visual phenomenon known as a floater. Floaters are small specks, spots, or \"cobwebs\" that seem to float in your field of vision. They tend to move around as your eyes move and are usually harmless. However, if you notice a sudden increase in the number or size of floaters, or if you experience flashes of light or a loss of peripheral vision, it is important to see an eye doctor immediately as it may be a sign of a more serious condition such as a retinal detachment. In the meantime, try to avoid activities that may make the floaters more noticeable, such as looking at bright lights or reading for extended periods.

instruction: Hello doctor,My tooth hurts anytime I eat or drink. It feels hot. I feel hot, it is sharp pain that does not go away. My gums are swollen.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have had permanent cramps and a constant ache in both buttocks. I have pain on both sides of my thighs and legs regardless of if I am sitting or resting.I got admitted to the hospital for two weeks and they did an MRI scan on my spine and found nothing. They did a lumbar puncture and found nothing. They also did a nerve examination and nothing was found. I am currently on Gabapentin, Codeine, and Paracetamol.

The fact that you have had an MRI and nerve examination done with no definitive diagnosis may suggest that the cause of your symptoms is musculoskeletal rather than neurological.

There are several potential causes of sciatica, including a herniated disc, spinal stenosis, or piriformis syndrome. However, it's worth noting that some cases of sciatica have no identifiable cause.

In terms of treatment, the medications you are currently taking can be effective at managing the pain associated with sciatica. However, other treatment options may also be helpful, including physical therapy, exercise, and certain types of injections.

It's also worth noting that lifestyle changes may help, such as regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, and practicing good posture.

I recommend discussing your symptoms with your doctor or a specialist such as an orthopedist, neurologist or pain management specialist to determine the best course of action for you.

instruction: Hello doctor,Last night and today I have been experiencing a sharp pain just left of the sternum which is not deep, seemingly on top of the rib where it joins the sternum. It lasts a second or two but may repeat several times before stopping in five minutes or so. I went out in the garden today to dig a bit and wearing my HR monitor (I have got health anxiety, anxiety disorder as well as depression). As I was digging, the pain started hurting with each heartbeat. I looked at my monitor and it read 138 bpm. I am 70 years old and have been on medication (Benzodiazepines) for over 50 years for panic attacks and general anxiety. Two years ago I felt similar pain but not to this extent. I went to ER but nothing was found (the doctor said it could be costochondritis but definitely not my heart). I get bloodwork quarterly and everything was fine except cholesterol which was 235. I tried a statin but the muscle pain was too great. In my EKG I have RBBB or LAFB which 14 years back after a stress test I was told that I was probably born with it. I had gone to see the cardiologist then because of getting skipped beats and GERD he told me to ignore them. Last time I had an EKG was in the ER for six months when I had a weird pain in back and side. They checked out heart anyway and said it was fine. Probably just a colicky gallbladder. I have had stones for more than 20 years and had no surgery. So I hesitate to go to the ER again. My local doctor just closed. HR is still 88 while lying down right now. Usually, my resting heart rate is under 67. Currently, I am on Lorazepam 2 mg, Prevacid 15 mg and baby Aspirin.
response:
Hello! Based on your description, it is possible that the pain you are experiencing is related to your musculoskeletal system, particularly costochondritis. This is an inflammation of the cartilage that connects the rib to the sternum, causing chest pain which can be sharp and aggravated by movement or deep breathing. It is typically not related to the heart, although chest pain should be evaluated by a doctor to rule out any cardiac issues.

Given your history of anxiety and depression, it is possible that your symptoms may be related to stress or anxiety. However, it is important to have a thorough evaluation by a doctor to determine the cause of your symptoms and any necessary treatment. If your local doctor is closed, you can consider seeking care at an urgent care center or emergency department.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am in my late 6th month pregnancy. Recently I went for a scan named targeted imaging for fetal anomalies (TIFFA). All the reports were normal except hypoplastic nasal bone and higher normal values of amniotic fluid. I am approaching you for second consultation now. My questions are, what if we go for genetic amniocentesis and results were positive for Down\\s syndrome? Can I terminate the pregnancy in my 28th week of pregnancy? How much safe it is to go for amniocentesis test? Is there any alternate test to get better results? I decided not to have a baby who is mentally retarded. Please suggest me your valuable advice.
response:
Hello, I'm an AI language model, and I'm happy to help you.

Firstly, it is important to note that the presence of a hypoplastic nasal bone and higher normal values of amniotic fluid are not definitive of Down Syndrome. They are merely soft markers and do not confirm the presence of the condition.

However, if you undergo genetic amniocentesis and the results come back positive for Down Syndrome, it is entirely up to you whether to terminate the pregnancy or not. It is a personal decision that depends on your beliefs and values.

If you do decide to undergo genetic amniocentesis, it is usually safe, but there are risks involved. There is a small risk of miscarriage and infection. You should discuss these risks with your doctor before deciding whether to proceed with the test.

Alternatively, you may consider non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT), which is a blood test that screens for genetic conditions. NIPT has a lower risk of miscarriage than amniocentesis, but it is more expensive.

Ultimately, the decision to undergo genetic testing and termination of pregnancy is a difficult one, and you should discuss your options with your doctor and loved ones. Also, it is important that you receive counseling and support throughout the process.

response:
The circumferential urinary bladder wall thickening versus under distension noted on your CT scan can have multiple causes, including bladder infections or inflammation, bladder stones, bladder cancer, bladder outlet obstruction, or radiation therapy. instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 50-year-old male. I had genital warts five years ago, had them removed via cauterization and received three injections of HPV vaccine Gardasil. The doctor said the vaccine would cure the virus, but after a year, warts reappeared and until now they are still in my scrotum, and they are itchy but not painful. My question is that can I have sex with my partner given my current condition? Have I got cured by HPV vaccine?
response:
Hello,

Firstly, it's important to know that the HPV vaccine does not cure an existing HPV infection, but it can help prevent future infections with certain strains of the virus.

Regarding your situation, while you may have been vaccinated against HPV, it sounds like you still have the virus since the genital warts reappeared. You should talk to your doctor about getting checked for any other strains of HPV that may be present.

In terms of having sex with your partner, it's recommended that you abstain until the warts have been treated and are no longer present. This is to reduce the risk of transmitting the virus to your partner. You should talk to your doctor about methods of treatment for the genital warts, which may include topical medications or surgical removal. Additionally, it's important to use condoms to reduce the chance of spreading the virus to your partner even after the warts have been treated.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am seeking experts to comment on low-carb diets.What is the complete macronutrient breakdown for a typical low-carb diet? How much fat should you eat on a low-carb diet? response:
Hello! As an AI language model, I can provide you with some general information on low-carb diets, but please note that for specifics, you should seek advice from a qualified healthcare professional.

The macronutrient breakdown for a typical low-carb diet can vary, but the aim is to typically limit carbohydrates to around 20-50 grams per day. This means most of the calories come from fat and protein. A common ratio is 60-75% fat, 15-30% protein, and 5-10% carbohydrates.

As for how much fat and protein to eat on a low-carb diet, it will depend on individual factors such as age, sex, activity level, and overall health. However, a general recommendation is to aim for about 1.5-2.0 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight, and enough healthy fats to meet calorie needs.

instruction: Hello doctor, I think I am bipolar. Just a couple of weeks ago, I felt and was told by my friends that I was more energetic and crazy than usual. Now, I feel like there is no hope, and nobody really cares. But there is also that little bit of me that is telling me that I am faking this and that all I want is attention. I just want to know what the heck is up with my head.
response:
Hello! It's great that you're reaching out for help. Bipolar disorder is a mental disorder that affects your mood and can cause extreme changes in your behavior and energy levels. It's characterized by episodes of mania (high mood, energy, and activity levels) and depression (low mood, energy, and activity levels).

It's important to note that only a mental health professional can diagnose bipolar disorder. If you are experiencing extreme mood swings, it's a good idea to speak to a doctor or a licensed therapist. They can evaluate your symptoms and help you determine the best course of action, whether that involves medication, therapy or both.

It's also common for people with bipolar disorder to struggle with feelings of doubt or guilt, especially during episodes of depression. It's important to recognize that these feelings are part of the disorder, and not a reflection of your character or worth. If you are struggling with these feelings, talking to a therapist or support group can be helpful.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am 29 years of age. I had unprotected sex and I am having sex with the same partner for more than a year and a half. Suddenly, I got itching sensation and found that I have got itchy bumps on my penis which started clustering together. Later, it healed automatically. I also found when I run or walk a long distance and feel sweaty, I feel the sensation and I get the bumps again. These bumps are small and shiny at the tip and often get clustered and gets healed. Also for a long time, I have itchy inner thighs because of which my skin turned blackish white and is still itchy. I am not sure whether I am infected. Based on your description, it is possible that you may have a sexually transmitted infection (STI) or a skin condition such as folliculitis. It is important to get a diagnosis from a healthcare provider by getting tested and examined.

It is recommended to avoid sexual contact until you receive a diagnosis and complete treatment if necessary. Also, avoid scratching the affected area to prevent the condition from worsening or spreading. 

Sharing pictures with a healthcare provider can be helpful in making a diagnosis but it is always best to consult with a healthcare provider in person.

instruction: Hello doctor,My uncle is 68 years old. He got a myocardial infarction 23 years back, and another one before 13 years, he had four bypasses that year. response: Based on the information provided, it is likely that your uncle is currently in Stage D heart failure which is the most severe stage of heart failure. The symptoms of shortness of breath, swelling in the abdomen and feet, wheezing, and coughing are all indicative of advanced heart failure.\n\nUnfortunately, the prognosis for Stage D heart failure is poor. However, this can vary depending on the severity of the heart failure, the underlying cause, and the patient's overall health and response to treatment. It is important that your uncle receives proper medical treatment and management of his heart failure symptoms to improve his quality of life and potentially extend his life expectancy.

instruction: Hi doctor, After shaving my face six days ago, I saw a big red bump on the right side of my nose above the mustache. At first, I thought it might be a pimple. Last week, I felt something wrong on my throat and visited a doctor. Doctor said lymph node inflammation and prescribed me Penicillin. Doctor did not ask me anything about that red bump in my mustache area at that time. I have been suffering from mild fever as well after my lymph inflammation. Right now I am worried again since the red bump on my mustache becomes large, and from two or three openings drains watery liquid when I tried to squeeze it. It is really painful and irritates a lot. I am worried about HSV 1 since it is near my mouth. I am having mild fever and lymph infection. I am not in sexual contact for the last seven years. What is your suggestion? What might cause this problem?
response:
Hello, based on your description, it is possible that the red bump on your nose above the mustache is a bacterial infection or an infected hair follicle. It is unlikely to be a manifestation of herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) since you haven't had sexual contact in the last seven years, and the bump is draining watery liquid when squeezed.

The mild fever and lymph node inflammation could also be caused by the same bacterial infection. The fact that you were prescribed penicillin by the doctor suggests that he or she suspected a bacterial infection.

However, if the bump on your nose persists or becomes worse, or if you develop other symptoms such as blisters or ulcers around your mouth, it is important to seek medical attention again to rule out other causes and receive appropriate treatment.

In the meantime, you can try to reduce the inflammation and pain by applying a warm compress to the affected area, and avoid squeezing or picking at the bump to prevent further infection. If the pain is severe, you may also take pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil), as directed by the package instructions or your physician.

instruction: Hello doctor,I recently tested positive for HIV and had a viral load test which was 160k and CD4 count of 145. My issue now is with how I could have contracted the virus. I have had three sexual partners and there was always protection. Two tested negatives after I informed them about my results and the last and most recent is insisting he is not ready and it was protected all the way. Although we did have anal at times and I cannot be 100 % sure that the condom was there. I have also had a parasitic infection which affects my scalp for a couple of years. Is it possible for something to mimic HIV in tests? I have been to the dentist thrice in all my life for an extraction and checkups. I also had an appendicectomy 13 years back. I have had occasional IV therapy and a few injections. I have never shown any symptoms. I am also anemic.
response:
I'm sorry to hear that you have tested positive for HIV. It's important to remember that HIV can be transmitted through unprotected sex, even if protection was used most of the time. Anal sex carries a higher risk of transmission than other sexual activities. It's also important to note that HIV can be transmitted through sharing needles or other injection equipment, but you didn't mention any history of drug use.

Regarding your question about the possibility of a mimicking parasitic infection, there is no known parasite or illness that can mimic HIV in laboratory testing. HIV testing involves detecting antibodies to the virus in your blood, as well as the virus itself, so it's highly unlikely that a different infection would give a false positive HIV result.

Your medical history and procedures you mentioned, such as dental extractions and injections, are not known to cause false positive HIV tests. Anemia is a common condition that can occur for a variety of reasons and is not directly related to HIV.

Going forward, it's important to prioritize your health and well-being by seeking treatment for HIV. Treatment with antiretroviral therapy (ART) can help suppress the virus, improve your CD4 count, and reduce your risk of complications. It's also important to communicate openly with your sexual partners about your HIV status and use protection consistently. Consider getting tested for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) as well, as people with HIV have an increased risk of acquiring and transmitting other STIs.

I encourage you to talk to your healthcare provider about your concerns and questions, and to work with them to develop a treatment plan that best meets your needs.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 26 year old female, and I developed foot drop five weeks ago, the foot was numb, and I could not dorsiflex it. But, now I can dorsiflex, and the steppage gait has disappeared unless I walk long distances. I have more power in the foot now, but it is still a lot weaker than the other one, I cannot walk on my heels yet. However, I have been extremely anxious about this foot drop, and a couple of weeks ago I started to twitch, first in the legs and then all over my body, I can see the twitches. When I am talking with someone and thinking about something else, the twitches go away and come back when I think about it. I do feel weak in my body, especially in the legs. Can it be due to the anxiety? I am going to a neurologist, but there is a three months waiting period, and I am scared. I do not think we have had any ALS in my family. Please help me ease my mind.
response:
Hello, I am sorry to hear that you are experiencing these symptoms. Foot drop can be caused by a variety of conditions, including nerve compression or damage, spinal cord injury or disease, and neurological conditions such as multiple sclerosis or ALS. It is important to see a neurologist to determine the cause of your foot drop, as they will be able to perform a thorough examination and order any necessary tests to make a diagnosis.

Regarding your twitching and weakness, while anxiety can certainly contribute to these symptoms, it is important to rule out any underlying neurological or medical conditions that could be causing them. It is good that you have an appointment with a neurologist, but if you are experiencing significant anxiety or worsening symptoms, it may also be worth discussing with your primary care physician about possibly seeing a specialist sooner or if any interim testing or specialists should be consulted.

It is also important to take care of your overall health and reducing stress can help manage symptoms. Practicing relaxation techniques such as meditation or yoga, and getting regular exercise or other forms of stress reduction can also help improve overall anxiety and well-being.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 33 years old and weighs about 86 kg. My whole body hurts. I got pain all over the body, pain in legs and hands. Pain is persistent all the time mostly in the lower feet and hand. I am having pain for the past three months. I just had an appointment with my doctor. He ordered some blood work and told me everything is fine. And he told me to see the rheumatologist once for my peace of mind.I have attached my report. Do you see anything abnormal in my blood report? What is the cause of my body pain? Is anything wrong with my body? Do I have any underlying conditions such as leukemia, lymphoma, or any other cancer? Do I have any liver disease or thyroid disease that can lead me to pain? Before three months I did a blood test and my rheumatoid factor was 8.1 iu/ml and now it is 11 iu/ml. Why it is going up with a short duration of time? What do I need to do?I am eating healthy and getting good sleep but I am not losing weight. My vitamin D level is 40ng/ml and I am taking vitamin B12. I am taking vitamin D for almost one year. I m taking 4000 IU for five days a week. Please explain in detail the treatment plan.
response:
Thank you for sharing your concerns and blood report with me. As a language model AI, I am not able to view the attached report. However, I can provide you with some general information and advice.

Body pain can be caused by various conditions such as fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, arthritis, or infections. Vitamin deficiencies or hormonal imbalances can also cause body pain. It is good that you have ruled out leukemia, lymphoma, or any other cancer with your blood test. Your doctor's advice to see a rheumatologist is reasonable as they specialize in treating conditions related to the joints, muscles, and bones.

Regarding your blood test, an elevation in rheumatoid factor does not necessarily mean that you have rheumatoid arthritis. It can occur in other conditions or even in healthy individuals. Your rheumatoid factor is only slightly elevated, so you may need further testing to determine if there is an underlying condition causing your symptoms.

While eating healthy and getting good sleep is beneficial for your overall health, weight loss requires a calorie deficit. You may want to consider consulting a registered dietitian for personalized nutrition advice and incorporating exercise into your routine to create a calorie deficit.

Regarding your vitamin D supplementation, a level of 40ng/ml is considered adequate. However, it is important to discuss with your healthcare provider whether you need to adjust your supplementation dose or frequency. Vitamin B12 supplementation is also important for maintaining nerve health and can be beneficial for chronic pain management.

In terms of treatment plan, it depends on the underlying cause of your symptoms. Seeing a rheumatologist can help determine the cause and an appropriate plan of care. They may recommend medications, physical therapy, and lifestyle adjustments to manage your symptoms.

In summary, body pain can have various causes and requires a thorough evaluation by a healthcare provider. I recommend following up with the rheumatologist and discussing any concerns or questions you may have.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am worried about ALS. I have had a twitch in my left hypothenar muscle intermittently for three weeks or so. The doctors have also performed basic finger strength tests (spread fingers and resist ) and they say they are normal. Reflexes are normal. response: Hello! It's understandable to be worried about ALS, but based on what you've described, it's unlikely that you have it. Keep in mind that anxiety and obsessive worrying can contribute to muscle twitching as well, so taking steps to manage stress and anxiety (such as exercise, meditation, or counseling) may help alleviate your symptoms.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 53 years old, and have quit smoking 19 years ago. I still have a chronic cough. Each specialist tells me something different. The pulmonologist told me it was asthma, and another doctor said it was acid reflux disease. Now they are telling me it is COPD. I do not have diminished lung capacity or problem in breathing, no wheezing, out of breath when I run but, I am overweight and out of shape. What do you think?
response:
It's challenging to diagnose the exact cause of your chronic cough without a thorough examination and medical history. However, based on your age, smoking history, and other symptoms, COPD could be a possibility. It's a chronic respiratory condition that may not have any visible symptoms until the disease progresses.

COPD can cause a long-term cough with phlegm, shortness of breath, and wheezing. However, some patients may also experience atypical symptoms or may not notice any symptoms at all until the disease progresses to a more severe stage.

It's also essential to note that acid reflux can cause a chronic cough, especially in patients without typical symptoms of acid reflux disease.

Obesity can also cause a persistent cough as excess weight can put pressure on your lungs and diaphragm and cause shallow breathing.

I would recommend consulting with your primary care physician or a pulmonologist to conduct a thorough evaluation to diagnose the root cause of your chronic cough. You may need specialized tests or imaging, such as a chest x-ray, CT scan, or lung function test, to confirm your diagnosis.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 21-year-old female. I have preauricular pits, that have drained smelly discharge ever since I was born. I have them in both ears. The right does not drain often. The left drains every day more than once a day. The left has become really swollen and painful recently. I am not sure of what to do because I now understand that the discharge means it is infected and it is hard for the surgery, if infected. Plus they have been infected for so long. I have also read that after surgery, it could reoccur.
response:
Hello,

Preauricular pits, also known as preauricular sinuses or ear pits, are congenital abnormalities that may lead to infections and discharge. If you have been experiencing smelly discharge from the pits since birth, it indicates that they are infected.

Infections in preauricular pits should be treated with antibiotics to reduce the risk of complications such as abscess formation or cellulitis. If the pit becomes swollen and painful, it could suggest a severe infection that needs prompt medical attention.

Surgical removal of preauricular pits is an option, especially for recurrent and infected pits. Surgery can be done when the infection has settled, and the wound has healed. It is essential to note that surgery can also carry a risk of complications, such as bleeding, wound infection, or recurrence.

It would be best if you talk to your primary care physician or an ENT specialist to assess the condition of your preauricular pits and discuss your treatment options.

I hope this helps.

instruction: Hello doctor,I was on a course of Deviry 10 mg for 5 days as I missed my period last month but I am not pregnant. How many days does it take to get my period now?
response: Deviry 10mg is a medication used to treat menstrual irregularities. It contains the hormone progesterone, which helps regulate the menstrual cycle. After taking Deviry, it usually takes a few days to a week for the period to start. However, it can vary from person to person. It is best to consult your doctor for further advice on when to expect your period.

instruction: Hi doctor,I had a cavity in the tooth. The X-rays show it was small but when the dentist drilled the nerve got exposed and is telling me I need a root canal along with crown. He has put a temporary filling for now. How do I know if I need a root canal for sure?
response:
If the nerve of your tooth has been exposed, it means that bacteria may have entered the pulp chamber of the tooth and caused an infection. A root canal is a process that aims to remove the infected or damaged pulp from the tooth's root canal and replace it with a filling material.

Usually, if your dentist recommends a root canal treatment for your tooth, it means that the nerve is damaged or infected, and the temporary filling was only added to alleviate pain until the root canal treatment can be performed.

If you are experiencing symptoms like pain, sensitivity to temperature, or swelling, it may indicate the need for a root canal. However, only your dentist can determine this after a thorough examination and analysis of your X-rays.

If you are unsure about the treatment plan or have any concerns, it is best to talk to your dentist and ask questions to fully understand the situation and what your options are.

instruction: Hello doctor,My mother was diagnosed with breast cancer early this year. She underwent MRM surgery and now undergoing chemotherapy. We find 17 more injections are too much and will be highly stressful for my mother. Could you please suggest an alternative treatment.I have attached a few essential reports for your reference. Please let me know if you need any more details.

Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your mother's condition. It is common for doctors to prescribe hormone blocking therapy after chemotherapy in patients with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.

The hormone blockers, also called endocrine therapy, work by blocking the action of hormones, such as estrogen, which may stimulate the breast cancer cells to grow. 17 more injections may seem like a lot, but it is a typical course of treatment that has been shown to be effective in preventing the cancer from coming back.

That being said, there are alternatives to hormone blockers that your mother may be able to discuss with her doctor. These alternatives include

instruction: Hello doctor,If both the testes experience a reduction in blood supply (and thus oxygen and hormones), in the long run will it increase the risk of more spontaneous mutation present in sperms as lesser blood supply will affect the DNA replication and repairing ability of spermatogonial cells?
response: Yes, a reduction in blood supply to the testes (also known as testicular ischemia) can increase the risk of mutations in sperm cells. This is because reduced blood supply can lead to oxidative stress and inflammation, which can damage the DNA in the sperm cells and impair their ability to repair themselves. Additionally, reduced blood supply can result in reduced levels of hormones that are essential for spermatogenesis and DNA repair. Therefore, testicular ischemia can increase the risk of sperm mutations and potentially lead to genetic abnormalities in offspring.

instruction: Hi doctor,My chief complaint is severe lower back pain and pain in upper thighs. My medical history is as follows. Carcinoma of the breast three years back, followed by surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. I am on Tamoxifen for past 3 years, and now I am taking Arimidex. I have been suffering from osteoporosis for over 7 years. Before six years, I had severe osteopenia with maximum bone loss of 21% on L3 and spine, ribs, trunk, and arms with more on the left side.I had undergone the following investigations. Before three years, I had FNAC which showed invasive ductal carcinoma, right breast ER+, PR+, Hercep score \"0.\" Last month, I had an x-ray and MRI, which showed focal altered marrow intensity lesions seen in B/L pelvic bone, sacrum, and left upper femoral shaft consistent with metastasis. I also had a PET scan which showed metabolically active ill-defined lytic destructive lesions in post cortex shaft of left femur, right inferior pubic ramus, B/L iliac bones, sacrum, D5, 7, 11 and L1, 4, sternum, right 3, 5, 7 post ribs with mid-right paravertebral soft tissue lesion at D7 level likely metastasis.
response:
I am sorry to hear about your medical history and your recent diagnosis of metastases. Your severe lower back pain and pain in upper thighs could be due to the spread of breast cancer to your bones, causing bone pain and fractures. The management of bone metastases involves a multidisciplinary approach with a focus on palliative care and pain management.

Your treatment options may include radiotherapy, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and bisphosphonate therapy. These treatments can help reduce pain, prevent further bone loss, and improve your quality of life. You may also be referred to a pain management specialist who can help you manage your pain effectively.

It is important to continue to follow up with your oncologist and other healthcare providers regularly to monitor the progression of your disease and adjust your treatment plan as needed. I wish you the best in your ongoing treatment and care.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have a squint in my right eye and it has moved outwards. I do not have a proper vision in my right. I cannot see clearly through my right eye; even I recognize thing pretty hard. I want to know whether it can be corrected, so that both my eyes work together. I am confused as I am now 26 years old. Is the correction going to be difficult at this age? I am looking up for a second opinion from you. Thank you.
response:
Hello! Thank you for approaching me with your concern. Squint, also known as strabismus, is a condition where the eyes are misaligned, and they do not look in the same direction simultaneously. It is most commonly seen in children, but adults can also have it. The degree of squint can vary from mild to severe, and it can affect one or both eyes.

The fact that you have a squint and have difficulties with vision in your right eye is concerning. It would be best if you visited an eye specialist for a complete eye examination to determine the cause of your vision difficulties and the extent of your squint. Some conditions like cataract, amblyopia (lazy eye), or an eye injury can cause squint, and they need timely intervention.

Regarding your concern about correction of squint, there's good news. It is possible to correct strabismus at any age, although treatment options may vary depending on the extent of the condition, presence of underlying eye problems, and age.

The treatment options for squint may include

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a female, 58, 5\\10\", 239lbs. I am having nausea every morning. It comes and goes during the day. I also have black stools, belly pain, and gas. I am on Lexapro 10 mg, Pramipexole 3 mg, Lamotrigine 25 mg twice daily and 200 mg once, Meloxicam 15 mg, Metformin 500 mg, Gabapentin 300 mg, and Atorvastatin 40 mg.
response: Hello! It sounds like you might be experiencing some gastrointestinal issues. The black stools could be a sign of gastrointestinal bleeding, which should be evaluated by your doctor immediately. The nausea and belly pain can be a symptom of many different ailments ranging from gastritis to more serious conditions like pancreatitis or hepatitis. I recommend you see your primary care physician or gastroenterologist as soon as possible to further assess your symptoms and determine appropriate testing and treatment. Additionally, your medications should be reviewed by your doctor to ensure that none of them are contributing to your symptoms.

instruction: Hi doctor,I took the first abortion pill but until now, I did not get bleed. What is the reason?
response:
There are several reasons why you may not have experienced bleeding after taking the first abortion pill. 

Firstly, the bleeding may not start immediately after taking the pill. It can take up to 48 hours or longer for the bleeding to start.

Secondly, if you took the first abortion pill within 24 hours of your missed period, you may not experience bleeding as your period may have already been on its way.

Thirdly, there is a possibility that the first pill did not work as it should have. In this case, you should speak with your healthcare provider regarding further treatment.

Finally, some women may experience minimal or no bleeding at all. This is a rare occurrence but can sometimes happen.

It is important to follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss any concerns or questions you may have regarding your abortion process.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 23-year-old male. I have no symptoms and I am not taking any current medication. Three years ago I once went to the hospital because I felt my heart was beating really fast, and they did some EKG scans and a blood test on me saying that everything is normal. They also gave me the Holter monitor and when they checked the results they said this was normal. I do not smoke or drink alcohol maybe three times a year I will drink. I used to do some shisha but that has stopped for the past three years.Since then I have never been to a hospital for the health of my heart. However, since then, my heartbeat has just been higher than everyone else but I do not get headaches or any other symptoms. I used to stress a lot. However, things are going well now and it has cut down. I wake up at times during the night but fall back asleep very easily. I have done gym and dance classes for over a year and I feel fine when working out.I went to the GP just a week ago due to my girlfriend having some concerns. I asked them to do a regular check and they said my heartbeat at that moment was 98 and he said this was fine. However, my girlfriend gets really worried about this and feels that something will happen to me. She just needs some medical advice in order to get her the assurance. She has been checking online for some answers and it is said stuff like arrhythmia, tachycardia, etc. She also says that the normal is between 80-100 bpm and why is mine on the top end? Is it a serious cause? Or does heart and pulse rate vary? Also, I have been checking the prevalence of heart diseases, etc., online and it is very rare for someone at my age. What more should be done?
response:
Hello! It's great that you are taking an interest in your health and seeking medical advice. Based on your description, your resting heart rate of 98 beats per minute (bpm) is slightly elevated but not necessarily a cause for concern. The normal range for resting heart rate is generally considered to be between 60-100 bpm, and can vary depending on age, gender, fitness level, and other factors. So, while it is true that a heart rate of 98 bpm is on the higher end of the normal range, it does not necessarily mean that you have a medical condition. 

It's also good news that your previous cardiac work-up, including EKG and Holter monitor, was normal. However, if your girlfriend is still concerned, I would recommend that you schedule a follow-up appointment with your primary care physician or a cardiologist. During this appointment, they can perform a more thorough evaluation, including a physical exam, and possibly recommend further tests such as an echocardiogram, stress test, or bloodwork. 

It's important to remember that the prevalence of heart disease and other cardiac conditions in young adults is relatively low, especially in the absence of risk factors such as high blood pressure, smoking, or family history of heart disease. However, maintaining a healthy lifestyle through regular exercise, a balanced diet, and avoiding smoking or excessive alcohol consumption is important for maintaining good cardiovascular health. 

I hope this information was helpful!

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 25-year-old male. I have only one testis. I have sexual feelings as a normal man would do. I am masturbating about once every week. Will a single testis cause any problem in the future? Recently, I had my first sex with my partner. At that time I was tensed and also had difficulty while penetrating her vagina. Please help.
response:
Hello,

Having only one testis is not necessarily a cause for concern and does not necessarily affect sexual function. However, it is important to have regular check-ups with a doctor to ensure that there are no underlying health problems that may affect sexual health.

Regarding the difficulty penetrating your partner's vagina, this could be due to various reasons such as anxiety, lack of experience, or possible physical conditions such as Erectile Dysfunction. It is recommended to talk to your healthcare provider to rule out any physical conditions and to discuss possible treatments. Furthermore, seeking help from a therapist or sex counselor may also be helpful in improving sexual experience, confidence and reducing anxiety.

Overall, having one testis should not limit your sexual experience, but it is important to have open communication with your healthcare provider about any concerns or limitations you may have.
