instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 19 year old girl. I have a very stupid habit that has caused a lot of problem for me, I have met a lot of psychologists, but I could never talk about my exact problem with them. It seems to be a ridiculous problem, but I ask your sincere help. When I was 15 years old, I watched a romantic movie which caused my problem, since then I made an imaginary life with an imaginary man in my mind. I have got involved with this problem for years. When I was a child, I had difficulties which I could not solve at that time, so I started fantasizing and tried not to involve myself in real life\\s problem. But then, there was no love in my imagination, I was a very happy successful girl, and I was a famous, respectful person.But after I got defeated at a state level game, I understood that I am not intelligent enough to achieve such goals, I was so depressed with no enthusiasm in studying. I got to know about sex and intercourse, I was confused and hated my gender, I thought of changing my gender. I had depression, and I was so disappointed about life. Then I started to imagine a man who lived with me, and I loved him so much. Instead of facing my life problems, I used to fantasize about him. From last year I have imaginary sex with him.The problem I have is that my life is interrupted by my imagination. I cannot deal with other students, especially boys. I have lost my confidence, do not have the enthusiasm to study. I cannot focus when I am in the class, and I do not take any efforts to solve my problem. I just keep imaging a peaceful life with no problems, sometimes when I cannot control my anxiety and stress, I start having sex in my mind. I do not know what to do, and I want to stop this imaginary life. How do I stop this imaginary life and love? I know this man is not real, and whenever my imaginary life becomes sad, it has an influence on my real life. I currently take tablet Levebel 500 mg, two tablets a day.
response:
Thank you for reaching out and sharing your struggle. It takes a lot of courage to ask for help. It sounds like you are experiencing a significant distress and disruption caused by this vivid imaginary life that you have created.

It seems like your imaginary life is serving as a way for you to cope and escape from the difficulties of real life. However, it's also causing you to miss out on the present and meaningful experiences that life has to offer.

The first step towards addressing this issue is acknowledging that you have a problem and seeking help. You mentioned that you've seen psychologists before but haven't been able to talk about this problem with them. I encourage you to try again and put your trust in a professional who is trained to help you work through these issues. You may consider finding a therapist who specializes in cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which can help you identify and change unhelpful thought patterns that are contributing to your obsessive thoughts and behaviors.

It's important to know that you are not alone in experiencing such thoughts and fantasies. Many people have struggled with similar issues and there is help available. It's important to remember that recovery is possible, and you can regain control over your thoughts and behaviors.

In addition to therapy, self-care practices such as regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, and mindfulness meditation can be helpful in reducing stress and anxiety. You may also try to engage in activities that connect you with others, such as joining a club or a hobby group.

Finally, please speak with your doctor about your medication and ask if any modifications need to be made to your prescription.

Remember, seeking help is a sign of strength, and there is no shame in talking to a professional about what you are going through. Take care of yourself.

instruction: Hello doctor,I and my partner had healthy sex. The next day she had periods and after six days we had unprotected sex due to which she had taken i-pill on that evening. Two months passed she still did not get her periods. I am worried. Please suggest any solution. Two years back also she has taken i-pill. This is the third time she is taking. Is it possible that she may not have periods for the whole life? Please help.
response:
Hello,

It is possible that the i-pill can cause a delay in periods. However, if your partner has not had her periods for two months, it is important to rule out pregnancy. I recommend that she takes a pregnancy test to confirm if she is pregnant or not.

If the test is negative, then the delayed periods could be due to the use of the i-pill, which can disrupt the normal menstrual cycle. The i-pill contains high doses of hormones, which can cause irregularities in the menstrual cycle.

It is unlikely that your partner will not have periods for her whole life. However, repeated use of emergency contraceptives like the i-pill can cause problems in the long term, such as irregular periods, hormonal imbalances, and fertility issues. It is advisable to use regular contraception methods such as condoms, birth control pills, or an IUD to avoid such problems.

In any case, I recommend that she consults a gynecologist to evaluate her menstrual irregularities and to suggest an appropriate treatment plan.

instruction: Hello doctor,My mother has abdominal tuberculosis, duodenum stricture, and obstruction in rectosigmoid and distal sigmoid colon. She does not take any food, not even liquid food. And she does not pass urine and stools from the past four months. Please help.
response:
I'm very sorry to hear about your mother's condition. It sounds like she is in a very difficult situation.

Abdominal tuberculosis is a serious condition that can cause a range of symptoms, including abdominal pain, weight loss, and fatigue. It can also cause strictures and obstructions in the digestive tract, which can make it difficult for your mother to eat, drink, and pass stools.

In this type of situation, it's important to get your mother to a doctor as soon as possible. She may need medical interventions to manage her symptoms and improve her quality of life, such as insertion of a nasogastric tube for feeding, or surgical intervention to remove the obstructions in her colon.

It's also important to address your mother's nutritional needs. She may benefit from working with a registered dietitian or nutritionist who can help develop a plan to meet her nutrient requirements without exacerbating her symptoms.

In terms of her lack of urine and stool output, this is a serious concern that needs to be addressed immediately. She may have a urinary or bowel obstruction, which could be life-threatening if left untreated. Please take her to the hospital or an urgent care center as soon as possible for evaluation and treatment.

I wish you and your mother all the best during this difficult time.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 30-year-old female. A thyroid profile done recently shows the TSH at 1.95, T4 at 13.9, and T3 at 113. I am on Eltroxin 100 mcg and folic acid. I am planning for pregnancy. Please advice.
response:
Hello! Your thyroid profile shows that you have a well-controlled thyroid function with adequate levels of TSH, T4, and T3. As you are planning for pregnancy, it is important to optimize your thyroid function and keep your TSH levels within the normal range. The recommended range for TSH during pregnancy is 0.1-2.5 mIU/L in the first trimester and 0.2-3.0 mIU/L in the second and third trimesters.

You are already taking Eltroxin 100 mcg, which is a synthetic form of thyroxine that is commonly used to treat hypothyroidism. You should continue taking this medication and get your thyroid levels checked regularly to ensure that your TSH levels remain within the optimal range during pregnancy. Maintaining good thyroid function is important for fetal brain development and can prevent complications during pregnancy.

Apart from thyroid medication, you should also ensure that you are following a healthy diet and lifestyle. Eat a balanced diet rich in nutrients such as folic acid, iron, and iodine, which are essential for the developing fetus. Exercise regularly and avoid smoking, alcohol, and drugs during pregnancy.

It is essential that you schedule regular prenatal visits with your obstetrician and endocrinologist to stay on top of your health and ensure that your TSH levels remain within the optimal range. They can adjust your medication dosage or type as necessary during pregnancy to ensure that your thyroid function is optimal.

I hope this advice helps. Good luck with your pregnancy!

instruction: Hello doctor,I have had every STD screen known to man and kidney function tests, my urine is foul smelling and dark. This has been an ongoing issue for a year and it has started to affect my life. I have tried everything. Antibiotics, hydration, douche, apple cider vinegar, AZO pills, yeast infection drugs, UTI drugs.
response:
It sounds like you are experiencing persistent symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) despite multiple rounds of treatment. Foul smelling and dark urine are common symptoms of a UTI. However, if you have been treated with antibiotics, it is possible that you may have developed a resistance to the antibiotics you have been receiving.

I recommend that you schedule an appointment with a urologist or infectious disease specialist for further evaluation. They may recommend additional testing, such as a urine culture, to identify the specific bacteria causing the infection and determine the appropriate antibiotics needed to treat it.

In the meantime, continue to drink plenty of fluids to help flush out any potential infections and maintain good hygiene practices. Avoid using douches, which can disrupt the natural balance of bacteria in the vagina, and use gentle pH-balanced soaps to clean the genital area.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have had four follicles ruptured from my left ovary and one from the right. I have had IUI back to back for two consecutive days. But my major concern is I have a unicornate uterus with a left rudimentary horn. I recently had lap because I had a cyst on my right ovary. The doctor says I have been ovulating perfectly every time. I am depressed abt the fact that left tube is absent but four follicles ruptured on the same side. Please give me some hope of getting pregnant. The endometrium lining is 9 mm which the doctor said is very good. And, this is my first IUI after lap.
response:
Hello,

Thank you for reaching out. I can understand that this is a challenging situation for you. It's positive that four follicles ruptured on the same side, as this increases your chances of successful pregnancy. However, the absence of the left tube is a concern as it can affect the ability of the egg to travel to the uterus.

That being said, having a unicornuate uterus with a rudimentary horn doesn't necessarily mean that you cannot conceive. It's important to follow up with your doctor regularly and monitor your ovulation to maximize your chances. Therefore, it is important to talk to your doctor about your current medication and discuss if there are any alternatives available that may be less likely to cause ED and EE.

Additionally, lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, healthy diet, and reducing alcohol and tobacco use can often help improve ED and EE. You can also try using vacuum pumps or penile injections, but it is important to speak to your doctor about these options first.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 19-year-old female. I lost my virginity about 10 months ago with my boyfriend. Now after 10 months has passed I found out that I have two warts inside my vagina. It is white color although, the one on the top started to have a slight pink color. But the second one on the bottom which is much smaller still has completely white color and around the vagina blades, I have a little while dots. Also, there are very tiny warts line along the blades. So, when I went to see the GP near my house he had a look and said that there is nothing to worry it is still small. But in my opinion, I think it is quite big. So the doctor gave me a prescription for Condyline paint which he told me to use for three days only per week and I have to keep using it for three weeks and if it does not get better he told me to see him again. Now I have a few questions. Is this mean I have an HPV virus inside my body? How can I make the virus go away permanently? Will Gardasil injection make it go away? If it does not go away permanently, how can I make sure that I have no HPV viruses and so these warts will not come back again? Is this mean that I have this HPV from my boyfriend? How to use Condyline paint correctly? I wash my vagina blades and use the cotton pads to dry it, then I use start to use the Condyline paint. I only dip the swab once into the reagent and then I open my vagina blades so that I am able to paint the two warts inside my vagina as much as I can. Then I paint it all over the very tiny warts in the vagina blades area. Am I doing it correctly?Now I have been using the Condyline for two days, but the very tiny warts that are around the vagina blades started to grow more. Is this mean anything? Can condoms prevent these HPV viruses? If I break up with my boyfriend, will this help my symptoms and health to become better? I am very scared of whether this can leads to cancer? I do not want this to ever happen to me again, how can I prevent this to happen again?If my warts are gone can I have sex with my boyfriend? Will these symptoms comeback again? If I decided to buy the Gardasil injection and injected it now, then the next after two months, then next after six months, but during this time can I have sex with my boy friend? Will the vaccine still work?
response:
Hi there,

I understand that you have several concerns and questions regarding the warts you have discovered in your vagina. I will try my best to provide you with useful information.

Firstly, it is highly likely that the warts you have are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is a sexually transmitted infection. However, not all HPV infections cause warts. The virus can lay dormant in your body for years without causing any symptoms.

Unfortunately, there is no cure for HPV, but there are ways to manage and treat the symptoms. The Condyline paint prescribed to you is one of the treatments available for genital warts. It is important to use it correctly to avoid any complications. The instruction leaflet that comes with the medication should provide you with detailed information on how to use it. You should also follow up with your GP if there are any concerns or if the symptoms persist after the treatment.

The Gardasil vaccine is available to prevent some strains of HPV that cause genital warts and certain types of cancer. However, it does not work for people who are already infected with HPV at the time of vaccination. It is recommended for girls and boys to receive the vaccine before they become sexually active to provide the best protection.

Using condoms during sexual activity can lower the risk of contracting HPV, but it is not foolproof. HPV can spread through skin-to-skin contact, so condoms may not always cover all the affected areas. It is also possible to contract HPV through oral sex, so it is important to practice safe sex all the time and to get regular screening tests.

Breaking up with your boyfriend may not necessarily help with the symptoms or prevent future outbreaks. HPV can be passed on even if the infected person appears healthy and may not even know they have the virus. The key is to maintain good hygiene practices and to get regular screenings.

The HPV virus can sometimes lead to cancer, but this is not always the case. Women who have had HPV-related genital warts are at a slightly higher risk of developing cervical cancer, so it is important to get regular cervical cancer screening tests as advised by your doctor.

Once the warts are gone, it is safe to resume sexual activity, but there is a chance that the symptoms may come back. This is because the virus may still be present in your body, and there is no cure for HPV. Continuing to practice safe sex and maintaining good hygiene practices can help reduce the risk of future outbreaks.

If you decide to get the Gardasil vaccine, it is okay to have sexual activity during the vaccination periods, but it is important to note that the vaccine may not provide the best protection if you are already infected with HPV.

I hope this information helps. It is important to have open communication with your doctor about your concerns and to follow their advice regarding treatment and prevention.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 57-year-old female. Here is my question constant heart palpitations and fluttering, continuous feeling of adrenaline rushing along with palpitations very bad at night but also during the day when sitting in doing nothing palpitations often make you feel nauseous on a 1 to 10 scale they are about an eight. All labs are normal ECG, echo, and Holter monitor are all normal.Doctor cannot figure it out and prescribed Propranolol 10 mg, told me to try these once a day. Yesterday after doctor visits heart palpitations for four hours got fed up and took one tablet one hour later, all palpitations and adrenaline rush was gone. Slept for the first time without being woke up having to cough to stop the palpitations. Had angio done approximately two years ago due to suspected heart attack or arrhythmia at home with all classic signs crushing chest pain jaw neck left arm down to the floor nauseated?Even with that lab test came back good the next day. Had carotid artery surgery two years ago to remove a piece of plaque in right carotid artery none found anywhere else no stent needed. Again all labs are good cholesterol not high on statins and warfarin. I must be perplexing to all doctors because they cannot figure it out. Was put on warfarin approximately 15 years ago due to DVTs as a result of a surgery, always therapeutic. So I had a heart attack or arrhythmia a few years back the angio came out the great doctor said everything looked fine now I have these crazy heart palpitations that would not stop. They go away as soon as I take the beta-blocker. I am told that beta-blockers even though anti-arrhythmic can also be pro arithmetic as well should I take this every day or should I only take this when I start to feel palpitations.
response:
First, it's important to note that I cannot provide specific medical advice without a formal evaluation. However, I can provide some general information and guidance.

Although your labs and tests are normal, it's still possible that you are experiencing some sort of arrhythmia. There are many different types of arrhythmias, and some can be difficult to detect on routine ECG or Holter monitor. Additionally, it's possible that you are experiencing a sensation of palpitations without actually having any significant arrhythmia. This can be caused by anxiety or stress.

Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to treat arrhythmias or palpitations. It works by slowing down your heart rate and reducing the force of your heart's contractions. However, as you noted, beta-blockers can also have proarrhythmic effects. This means that they can sometimes cause or worsen arrhythmias, especially in people with certain underlying conditions.

Given your history of a possible heart attack or arrhythmia, as well as your ongoing symptoms, it may be worth considering further testing or evaluation. This could include a more extended or continuous monitoring period, such as an implantable loop recorder. Additionally, if your symptoms are truly bothersome or affecting your quality of life, treatment options beyond beta-blockers may be worth exploring.

In terms of how to take the propranolol, it's best to follow your doctor's specific instructions. If they prescribed it to be taken daily, it's likely because they feel that you will benefit from its effects on an ongoing basis. However, if you are only experiencing occasional symptoms, it may be reasonable to take it as needed, under the supervision of your doctor.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 49-year-old woman and last month I was hospitalized with a necrotizing soft tissue infection on my thigh. I had two debridement surgeries and was discharged after 5 days. I was treated with about 4 IV antibiotics. I do not remember them all, I recall seeing Vancomycin and Penicillin. I was told that the infection was not MRSA, but a \"slower moving bacteria\" they did not tell me what it was. I was swabbed for MRSA in my nose and butt before both surgeries and was told I did not have it. For the last day of my stay, I had a roommate who had a bad MRSA infection on her butt and sometimes had diarrhea incontinence during dressing changes. I had no physical contact with her, but we had the same nurse. I was discharged with a five day course of Augmentin.The wound has been healing very well and has not gotten infected, but three weeks after discharge I got an abscess under my arm. I went to an urgent care and was prescribed Clindamycin and told to return in three days for drainage. The abscess did not improve or get worse over the three days. I got it drained and was prescribed Augmentin and told to also continue the clindamycin. That was a week ago and the wound is healing well. They called today and said cultures show it was MRSA and they prescribed Bactrim and told me to stop the other antibiotics.I am feeling devastated by this and wanting to understand why it happened. Could I have gotten it in the hospital? I am concerned that it will not go away. Are those swabs at the hospital conclusive and mean for sure I did not have MRSA a month ago? I have never had any medical problems before and these experiences have been very frightening. Is there anything else I can do to prevent recurrence? I have read about everything from bleach baths and hibiclens to antibiotics in the nose.
response:
I understand that this has been a frightening experience for you. It is possible that you may have acquired MRSA in the hospital, even if the swabs did not detect it at the time. MRSA can be carried on the skin without causing an infection, and it is possible for it to develop into an infection later on. Additionally, being in close proximity with a patient with MRSA may have increased your risk of acquiring it.

In terms of preventing future recurrence, practicing good hygiene, such as washing your hands frequently, using bleach baths or hibiclens, and using antibiotics in the nose may be helpful. It may also be important to maintain good overall health, as people with weakened immune systems or underlying medical conditions may be more prone to infections.

It is important to continue taking the prescribed antibiotics as directed and follow up with your healthcare provider as instructed. They can monitor your progress and provide additional guidance and treatment as needed.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a sufferer of hemiplegic migraine. However, I had unusual collapses three months back. The first one was 40 minutes; I could not recall the whole of that period. I came back with an injured knee and felt dazed. I was fine after around two hours. The next day, I felt pressure in my head and as though I was about to die. I then could not recall getting home or the rest of the night. I was fine in the morning. Two days later, I felt horrendous pain in my head, felt like I was swimming, then tried to go home and again could not recall from deciding to go home to around two hours later and I was foggy for the rest of the night. I have had constant pain in the left side of my head above the temple for four years. It does not go. However, In the past two weeks, I have felt like it is throbbing and at times about to burst out. I was meant to see my neurologist three months back, but his receptionist did not follow the recommendation, and now I am unsure whether to have the tests done. I feel like we are playing with my life. Usually, I am pretty relaxed about the possibilities and know it is a migraine. But this feels different. This feels like intense throbbing above my ear from the temple along towards the back of my head, with a pain in my ear to just behind my jaw under my ear. My instinct says that an aneurysm needs ruling out. I do not know if I am just upset because it feels so different and this pressure is intense. It is a weird feeling. I currently take Sumatriptan as needed.Please, can you advise what to do? As it stands the next neuro appointment is after four months, added complication is that I have been breathless and unable to climb stairs without stopping and panting for past four months. I am having heart tests on the weekend. But, what do I do about my brain?
response:
Hello,

I understand your concern regarding your symptoms. The throbbing pain in your head, coupled with the memory lapses and dizziness, could indicate the possibility of an intracranial issue like an aneurysm. I would suggest you see a neurologist as soon as possible to rule out any serious conditions like an aneurysm.

Please do not delay any longer in seeking medical attention just to be safe. In the meantime, you may wish to take the prescribed medication 'Sumatriptan' for migraine relief when needed.

Regarding your breathlessness and difficulty climbing stairs, please follow up with your doctor and undergo the recommended heart tests to determine the cause.

I hope this information is helpful to you. Please let me know if you have further questions or concerns.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am 32 years old married male. Since two years I am suffering from premature ejaculation. I tried to control it, but did not get better result. My wife is very much unsatisfied. How to cure this issue?
response:
Premature ejaculation is a common problem that can be managed with proper treatment. There are several treatment options available to manage premature ejaculation, including medication, counseling, and behavioral techniques.

Medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), topical numbing creams, and phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE5) inhibitors can help delay ejaculation. Counseling can help you understand and address any underlying psychological issues that might be contributing to your problem.

Behavioral techniques such as the start-stop technique, the squeeze technique, and pelvic floor exercises can also help you delay ejaculation during sex.

It is important to talk to your healthcare provider to determine the right treatment option for you based on your overall health and any underlying medical conditions you might have. They can also provide information and resources to help you manage your condition effectively.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 32 years old and unmarried. I am a patient of PCOD. I also have a family history of breast cancer. My father\\s sister had breast cancer recently. I am in a very big financial crisis. So, one of my friends suggested me to donate eggs. Will it be risky if I donate my eggs only once? As I am a patient of PCOD, will I be able to conceive in the future? Will I be given some hormonal treatment to conceive later? Please advise me whether I should proceed with the idea of egg donation. Is there any chance of developing breast or ovarian cancer if I donate eggs? Please guide me. I just want to know about its long term consequences as I am afraid of breast and ovarian cancer.
response:
Hello,

Thank you for reaching out. I understand your concerns and am happy to provide some information to help you make an informed decision.

Firstly, as a patient with PCOD, it may be more difficult for you to conceive naturally. However, this does not necessarily mean that you will not be able to conceive. Your fertility specialist can recommend therapies and medications that can help you ovulate and conceive. Additionally, it's essential to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle to optimize your chances of getting pregnant.

As for egg donation, it is a safe procedure that has helped many couples conceive. However, it is not recommended for everyone. The donation process requires you to undergo treatment that stimulates your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. This medication can potentially worsen your PCOD symptoms and may lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) if not monitored carefully.

Regarding the risk of cancer, studies have not found a significant difference between the incidence of cancer in donors compared to the general population. However, there is still some uncertainty about the long-term effects of egg donation. Therefore, it is essential to discuss these risks with your fertility specialist before making a decision.

In conclusion, egg donation can be a life-changing experience for couples struggling with infertility. However, as a PCOD patient, it is crucial to discuss your options with your physician and understand the potential risks and long-term consequences before making a decision.

I hope this helps. Best of luck with your decision.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 26 year old female. I am worried after reading about the effects of radiation from a CT scan. I had two separate scans within a month. Both the scans were for the chest, abdomen, and pelvis. The doctors were looking for a potential lymphoma, but nothing conclusive was found. I am worried about the future cancer risk. Please help.
response:
Hello, I understand your concern. It is true that CT scans involve exposure to ionizing radiation, which can increase your risk of cancer. However, the risk is generally very small and the benefits usually outweigh the risks.

The radiation dose from a CT scan varies depending on the type of exam, the area of the body being scanned, and the individual patient's size and age. In general, the radiation dose from two separate CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis would be higher than from a single scan.

It is difficult to estimate your individual risk of developing cancer from these scans, as it depends on many factors. However, the American College of Radiology has stated that the increased risk from a typical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is estimated to be low, with a potential lifetime risk of fatal cancer estimated to be 0.1%. This means that out of 1,000 people who undergo such scans, one might die from radiation-induced cancer.

It is important to remember that CT scans are extremely useful diagnostic tools that can help detect potentially life-threatening conditions, such as lymphoma. In cases where the benefits of the scan outweigh the risks, it is important to undergo the scan.

If you are still concerned, you can talk to your doctor about ways to reduce your radiation exposure, such as using alternative imaging techniques, such as MRI or ultrasound, or by using lower-dose CT protocols.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am hepatitis B patient. My current status is as follows. HBeAg - negative (0.010), HBV E antibody or Ag - positive (0.031) and HBV DNA quantitative (PCR) less than 17.1 IU/mL. Please advise whether this can be cured to become negative as it is affecting my career.

Hepatitis B is a chronic viral infection that affects the liver. The goal of Hepatitis B treatment is to prevent the virus from replicating, decrease the risk of complications such as liver cirrhosis or cancer, and improve the quality of life of patients. Although some patients may clear the virus on their own, most people with chronic Hepatitis B require long-term or lifelong treatment.

The fact that your HBeAg is negative and your HBV DNA is less than 17.1 IU/mL are positive signs, indicating that there is low replication of the virus. However, it is essential to consult your doctor, who can evaluate your case, determine the best course of action, and monitor your Hepatitis B status over time.

Treatment options for Hepatitis B include antiviral medications such as interferon-alpha and oral nucleoside/nucleotide analogs. Your doctor can advise you on the suitability of these treatments for you and the potential benefits and risks of each option.

It is also crucial to adopt a healthy lifestyle, avoid alcohol, and follow appropriate vaccination guidelines. Additionally, it is crucial to inform your sexual partners and household contacts and encourage them to get tested and vaccinated against Hepatitis B.

Please consult your doctor for advice on your specific case.

instruction: Hello doctor,I had all four wisdom teeth pulled nine days ago. Only the one on the bottom right tooth is very painful and when I push near it all this foul smelling yellow stuff comes out. What is wrong? Also, having headaches.
response:
It sounds like you may have a dry socket in the area where the tooth was pulled. A dry socket occurs when the blood clot that forms in the socket after a tooth is removed becomes dislodged or dissolves too early, leaving the bone exposed. This can be extremely painful and can cause a foul-smelling discharge.

You should contact your dentist or oral surgeon immediately to have the dry socket treated. They may need to clean the socket and place a medicated dressing in it to promote healing and relieve pain.

As for the headaches, they may be related to the pain and stress of the extraction or could be a separate issue. If they persist, you should also discuss this with your dentist or primary care physician.

instruction: Hi doctor,What is the difference between IntraLasik and Contoura Lasik?
response:
IntraLASIK and Contoura LASIK are both advanced technologies used in laser eye surgery to correct refractive errors such as myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. However, they are slightly different from each other.

IntraLASIK, also known as Bladeless LASIK, is a femtosecond laser-assisted LASIK surgery. It involves creating a corneal flap using a femtosecond laser instead of a microkeratome blade, as in traditional LASIK. This technology is known for its precision and reduces the risk of complications during the procedure.

Contoura LASIK, on the other hand, is a type of custom LASIK procedure that uses topography-guided laser technology. It creates a detailed map of the cornea, including all of its subtle irregularities, and uses this information to make highly precise laser treatment patterns. This technology can provide better outcomes for patients with highly irregular corneas, such as those with keratoconus.

In summary, IntraLASIK is a variation of LASIK that uses a laser to create the corneal flap, while Contoura LASIK is a custom LASIK procedure that uses topography-guided laser technology. Your ophthalmologist will recommend which procedure is the most appropriate for your particular situation.

instruction: Hi doctor,I started with the gym last week. I trained myself at home for a few weeks. After going to the gym, I began to have pain in the knees. It hurts me a lot. I am unable to do squats for a week. I tried to fix it, and nothing helped me. I do not know what to do. Please help.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your pain. Knee pain is a common complaint in individuals starting a new workout routine or going to the gym after a break. It's essential to identify the exact cause of the pain to guide treatment. Overuse can cause muscle, joint, and tendon pain, or even inflammation.

To ease your pain, you can try RICE therapy - rest, ice, compression, and elevation - to help decrease inflammation and relieve pain. Avoiding activities that provoke the pain is also essential. You can modify your exercise routine and activities, such as avoiding high-impact activities like running and jumping.

It's crucial to see a doctor, especially if the pain persists, increases, or limits your mobility. They can assess the cause of your pain and recommend appropriate treatment, such as medication, physiotherapy, or referral to a specialist. They may suggest an MRI to identify any soft tissue (ligaments, tendons, muscles) damage or cartilage or bone injury.

In the meantime, focus on gentle exercises like walking, low-impact exercise, and stretching, until the pain subsides. Make sure to engage in proper warm-up and cool-down routines before and after exercise. Staying hydrated, getting enough rest, and eating a balanced diet can also help reduce inflammation and promote healing.

I hope this helps. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to see a doctor.

response: It is difficult to diagnose a skin lesion without seeing it in person or a picture. instruction: Hello doctor,When I was 11 years old, I was knocked off my bike and cracked my front tooth in half horizontally, shortly after the dentist fixed it. Since then I have had no problems with it and had multiple x-rays to check on it. When it happened, the color of the tooth changed very slightly, to a very slightly more yellow shade than the rest of my teeth. I am curious to know what happened when the trauma occurred. Did my tooth die? What are they checking for when they x-ray the tooth?
response:
Hello,

I'm glad to hear that you have had no problems with your tooth since the accident.

When trauma occurs to a tooth, the nerve and blood vessels inside the tooth can be damaged. This can cause the tooth to become non-vital, which means that the nerve and blood supply to the tooth are no longer working. When this happens, the tooth can become discolored.

In your case, it's possible that the tooth became non-vital following the trauma, which is why it became slightly discolored. However, if you haven't had any problems with the tooth since the accident, it's possible that the nerve and blood supply were not significantly damaged.

When your dentist X-rays your tooth, they are checking to see if there are any signs of damage inside the tooth. This can include looking for signs of infection, decay or damage to the root.

I hope this helps answer your questions. If you have any more concerns or questions, feel free to ask.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 68 years old with a weight of 76 kg and a height of 5 feet 9 inches. I had a bypass surgery seven years ago. I used to walk 45 minutes daily. I feel completely fit and fine. A week ago, I felt that my heart rhythm was irregular. After going through a Holter test, I found that my heart rate increases and slows down with a pause of 1.8 seconds. My minimal heart rate is 50 and the maximum is 144 BPM. My average heart rate is 89. Is there anything serious?More details about the presenting complaint include I rarely get a headache with no other symptoms. I am currently taking Razel Gold once a day. In the past, I have been on Concor 5 mg once a day and Razel Gold once a day. I have gone through TMT three to four months ago with a normal outcome. The doctor also did an echocardiogram and everything seemed normal. Please help.
response:
Based on the information you've provided, it seems likely that you are experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation, which is an irregular heart rhythm. Since you had a bypass surgery seven years ago, it is possible that your heart condition may be worsening. The pause of 1.8 seconds is concerning, as it can lead to dizziness, fainting, and other complications.

You should speak with your doctor about your symptoms and test results. They may recommend additional tests, such as a stress echocardiography, to evaluate your heart function further. Depending on the severity of your symptoms, they may recommend medication or a pacemaker to regulate your heart rate.

In the meantime, it's important to monitor your symptoms and avoid any activities that could trigger your irregular heart rhythm. This may include reducing your caffeine intake, limiting alcohol consumption, and avoiding strenuous exercise until your condition is properly managed.

Overall, it's important to work closely with your doctor to manage your heart health and prevent any further complications.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have a small freckle about 3-4 mm on the side of my foot. It is not different from my skin in appearance. It just seems to be a brown blemish. I think, I have it for a number of years and now I am a bit anxious about what it could be. Thank you.
response:
Hello! Thank you for bringing this up. In general, small freckles that appear normal in color and size do not usually indicate a serious condition. However, it is always best to have any changes in your skin examined by a doctor, especially if it is causing you anxiety. 

If the freckle has been present for a long time and has not changed in appearance, it is less likely to be a cause for concern. However, if the freckle has any irregular features such as asymmetry, uneven color, or changes in size or shape, it may be worth getting it checked out by a dermatologist. They may recommend performing a biopsy to rule out any potential skin cancers or diseases.

In the meantime, it is important to monitor the freckle to see if there are any changes in size, shape, or color. It is also crucial to practice good sun protection by wearing sunscreen and avoiding prolonged exposure to the sun, as this can increase the risk of developing skin cancers.

I hope this helps!

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 35 years old. My period was a month back. It sustained for four days. I generally use 3 to 4 pads in my periods. I had sex 10 days later. On the very next day, I had two Ovral G at around 9 AM and there after 12 hours again two Ovral G tablets. I noticed my period 12 days later, though it lasted for four days, the period was less and usually, my period happens four days earlier. In this month, it was six days earlier. I did hCG beta blood test. I am sending you the report. Can I be pregnant or conceive? Please advise because I want to abort. I am an unmarried woman. Can the blood test be wrong? What laboratory test I should do to get to know whether the fetus is there beyond uterus (ectopic pregnancy) as I m 35+. When should I go for ultrasound vagina testing to get the true picture? After that I did not have any sex, so then again can I be pregnant and that could not be detected now and can be detected on later?
response:
Based on the blood test results you provided, your hCG levels are very low, indicating that you are most likely not pregnant. However, it is important to remember that no method of contraception is 100% effective, so there is always a small chance of pregnancy even when using birth control pills.

If you believe you may be pregnant and want to confirm this, I would recommend repeating the hCG beta blood test after a week or two to see if your levels have increased. Alternatively, you could take a home pregnancy test, but keep in mind that these tests are not as sensitive as a blood test and may not detect early pregnancies.

If you suspect that you may have an ectopic pregnancy, there are several tests your doctor may recommend. In addition to a pelvic exam and ultrasound, they may perform beta hCG blood tests over several days to track whether your levels are increasing or decreasing.

If you decide to terminate a pregnancy, I would strongly advise seeking the help of a medical professional. Abortion is a safe and legal procedure when performed by trained healthcare providers, and they can also provide you with information about contraception options to prevent future unintended pregnancies.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am hoping you can advise me. I have a mole on my chest that has been changing for about a month now. It is itchy at times and it has bled (small spots) as I am sure from the itching. I am worried it is skin cancer. Can you help?
response: Hello, I can understand your concern. It is essential to get your mole examined by a dermatologist or a doctor who specializes in skin diseases. instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 41-year-old female and have been diagnosed with viral conjunctivitis by a specialist. My eye health is otherwise perfect (had them checked out a week before this came on). After a few days, it spread to the other eye. I expect the first eye will heal first, even though the second eye is not as bad. One question is when the first eye heals, do I need to protect it from re-infection from the one that is still healing?Also, on the typical length of healing, I am not quite at two weeks yet (this is day 11 for the first eye), but the lack of improvement in my condition is becoming frustrating to me. Today the vision in the first eye is smudgy, and the vision in the second eye is better, but not perfect. The specialist was aware of the vision problems, and she said that it was normal (though I think they have worsened).I was told this could take weeks to heal, beyond the normal one or two. How many weeks are weeks generally? I was told I have a mild to moderate case, but all I know is that I have seen no real progress, and I think the virus might have even spread to one of my sinuses. My mental health is suffering from not knowing how long I am going to be cooped up, partially visually impaired and contagious. Am I impatient or should I have them looked at by a specialist again?
response:
Hello! I'm sorry to hear about your viral conjunctivitis. Protecting your first eye from re-infection is a good idea, especially if you have been touching your eyes with your hands or using the same towel or facecloth to wipe your eyes. Make sure to practice good hygiene, such as washing your hands frequently and avoiding touching your eyes, to prevent spreading the infection.

The length of healing for viral conjunctivitis can vary, but typically it takes about 1-2 weeks for the symptoms to resolve. However, some cases may take up to several weeks to completely clear up. If you have been experiencing worsening symptoms or no improvement after two weeks, it may be a good idea to follow up with your specialist to ensure proper treatment and management of any complications.

It is understandable that your mental health may be suffering from this prolonged illness, but try to focus on self-care and looking after yourself during this time. Resting your eyes and using warm compresses can help relieve symptoms, and avoiding exposure to irritants such as smoke or allergens can help prevent further discomfort.

instruction: Hello doctor,I was chewing tobacco for the past few years. And I stopped it forever. But sometimes I have a little throbbing on my gums. And the color of my gums changed to black. Is this any serious disease?
response:
Hello. The symptoms you are describing are typically associated with a condition called "oral submucous fibrosis" which can occur due to the prolonged use of tobacco. It can cause pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, and discoloration of the gums.

The discoloration you are describing may be due to pigmentation changes caused by the tobacco use or it may be due to the oral submucous fibrosis.

I recommend that you consult with a dentist or oral physician for a thorough examination and further treatment recommendations. You may require medications or other therapies to manage the symptoms and prevent further progression of the condition. In addition, it is important to continue to stay tobacco-free to prevent further damage to your oral health.

The test involves injecting a small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) under the skin and then checking the injection site for a reaction after 48-72 hours. If a raised red bump appears at the site, it may indicate a previous or current tuberculosis infection. In your case, it would be best to consult with a healthcare provider who can review the results of your skin test and provide an accurate diagnosis based on your medical history and physical examination.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 33 years old, male. I am diagnosed with right adhesive otitis with left SOM. Already mastoidectomy was done in right ear nine years back and two myringotomies in right ear when I was 4 and 7 years of age. I have CT scan report, audiometry, impedance test results.
response:
Hello,

Thank you for providing that information. Based on what you have shared, it sounds like you have a complex history with your right ear and some issues with your left ear as well.

Adhesive otitis is a condition where the middle ear space becomes filled with a sticky fluid that can cause hearing loss and ear infections. SOM stands for serous otitis media which is another type of middle ear fluid that can cause hearing loss and pressure sensations in the ear.

A mastoidectomy is a surgical procedure to remove the air cells in the mastoid bone behind the ear in order to prevent or treat infections that have spread from the middle ear. Myringotomy is a procedure to create a small hole in the eardrum in order to drain fluids that have built up.

To properly evaluate your condition and develop a treatment plan, it would be helpful to review your CT scan, audiometry, and impedance test results. If it has been a while since your last evaluation, it may also be necessary to perform additional tests to fully understand the current status of your ears.

I would recommend scheduling an appointment with an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist to discuss your options and develop a plan for managing your condition. Depending on the severity of your symptoms, treatment may involve medications, additional surgeries, or the use of hearing aids.

I hope this information is helpful, and I wish you the best of luck in finding relief from your symptoms.

instruction: Hi doctor,My nephew is a premature baby. On the third day, his blood glucose level was decreased to 34. Later, he was admitted and kept under surveillance. His blood test revealed elevated bilirubin level. Four days later, his blood values become normal. On the same day, suddenly there was swelling on his body. The biochemistry examination revealed urine spot protein to creatinine ratio 2.19 and moderate grade proteinuria.
response:
Hello! It is not uncommon for premature babies to experience health complications in the first few days and weeks of life. It sounds like your nephew has had a few concerning symptoms and laboratory findings. 

The low blood glucose level on day three could be due to a variety of reasons, including immaturity of the baby's liver, poor feeding or a condition called hypoglycemia of infancy. Elevated bilirubin levels are also not uncommon in premature babies, as their livers are not yet fully developed to process bilirubin effectively. This condition is known as jaundice.

Proteinuria (the presence of protein in the urine) can be an indication of kidney damage. A urine spot protein to creatinine ratio of 2.19 and moderate grade proteinuria are both concerning findings. The swelling on his body could also be a symptom of damaged kidneys, or it could have a different underlying cause.

It is important that your nephew is under close surveillance and that his healthcare team is monitoring his symptoms and laboratory findings closely. He may need further testing or interventions to address the proteinuria and other symptoms. It is best to reach out to his healthcare provider for guidance on how to proceed.

instruction: Hello doctor,Why some men cannot grow full beards? Explain why some men are not capable of growing full beards, and can only manage thin, patchy ones. Is this due to testosterone and genetics or something more? How does not being able to grow a full beard potentially impact men psychologically? Can this be emasculating for men or cause issues with self-esteem? Is there anything patchy men can do?
response:
Hello! The ability to grow a full beard is largely dependent on genetics and testosterone levels. Testosterone is the hormone that stimulates and controls the growth of facial hair, and genetics determine how sensitive the hair follicles are to testosterone.

Some men may have lower levels of testosterone or less sensitivity to the hormone, which can result in thin or patchy beard growth. Other factors such as age, health, and diet may also play a role in beard growth.

Not being able to grow a full beard can potentially impact men psychologically, causing feelings of inadequacy or emasculation. This can affect self-esteem and even lead to social anxiety. However, it is important to note that not being able to grow a full beard does not define one's masculinity or worth as a person.

If a man is struggling with patchy beard growth, there are a few things he can do to improve it. Eating a balanced diet and getting enough sleep and exercise can help boost testosterone levels naturally. Using a beard oil or serum can also help to nourish and stimulate the hair follicles. If these methods do not work, there are also medical treatments such as minoxidil or hair transplant surgery available. However, it is important to speak with a doctor or dermatologist before trying any treatments.

My concern is today I noticed my foreskin has become swollen and looks similar to a balloon. The stitches are preventing me from pulling my foreskin back over the glans. So, it has been retracted all this time. Is the swelling normal and due to the incision or is it not normal? Also, am I suppose to keep it pulled back or do I try to push it back over the glans? My glans is very sensitive. So, it feels like an electric shock every time I move.
response: Hello. Swelling after a frenuloplasty is normal and can be due to the procedure or the tissue healing process. However, if the swelling is excessive or causing discomfort, it's best to contact your urologist as soon as possible to ensure there are no complications. As for the foreskin, it's best to keep it retracted, as pulling it over the glans may cause further discomfort and potentially disrupt the stitches. It's important to follow the aftercare instructions given by the nurse, including washing the area twice daily and keeping it clean and dry. If you experience any excessive pain, bleeding, or discharge, please contact your urologist right away.

instruction: Hi doctor,My mother got a sudden heart pain. I took her to the hospital. After ECG And further processing, we came to know that she got ischemic heart disease and her two valves of the heart are closed. She has diabetes and blood pressure problems due to which atherosclerosis occurred three days ago. The doctor told him for angiography. Are angiography and stent good for her? Please also tell me about everything related to heart problems cure and heart diet.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your mother's heart condition. Angiography is a diagnostic test that will help doctors determine the extent of the blockages in her arteries. Based on the severity of the blockages, doctors can then recommend the appropriate treatment which may include stenting.

Stenting is a minimally invasive procedure where a small, mesh tube is placed in the blocked artery to help keep it open and reduce the risk of a heart attack. It can be a good treatment option for certain types of blockages.

However, the decision to undergo angiography and stenting will depend on the overall health of your mother and the extent of her blockages.

In terms of heart disease prevention and management, guidelines recommend adopting a healthy lifestyle with a heart-healthy diet, regular exercise, and quitting smoking if applicable. The diet should focus on whole foods, with plenty of fruits and vegetables, lean proteins, whole grains, and healthy fats like those found in nuts and fatty fish. It's also important to limit processed foods, added sugars, and saturated and trans fats.

Additionally, managing blood pressure, diabetes, and cholesterol levels are crucial in preventing and managing heart disease. Medications may be prescribed to help keep these conditions under control.

It's important to work closely with a healthcare provider to develop a comprehensive treatment plan for managing heart disease.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have personal dermatitis. I was prescribed 12 weeks of 100 mg Doxycycline. However, I am skeptical about taking antibiotics as I have read that with a lot of people the rash returns upon finishing treatment. Also, it can mess up your gut which is apparently linked to perioral dermatitis. I have gone gluten, dairy and sugar free, started Probiotics, Zinc and Omega 3 supplements and the rash still persists. I also use Metro gel and also it helps my rash is still there. It is mild but is very annoying and sore. If I take antibiotics will it make things worse? Or should I go get allergy testing? I have also cut out flouride toothpaste and eliminated SLS.
response:
Hello, thank you for reaching out. Perioral dermatitis can be a frustrating condition to manage, and it's understandable to have some concerns about taking antibiotics.

Doxycycline is often used to treat perioral dermatitis, and it can be effective in clearing up the rash. However, as you mentioned, there is a risk of the rash returning after stopping treatment. Antibiotics can also disrupt the gut microbiome, which can contribute to the development of skin issues like perioral dermatitis.

Your current approach of eliminating trigger foods and using topical treatments like Metro gel is a good one. You may want to consider working with a dermatologist or other healthcare provider to explore additional treatment options.

Allergy testing may be helpful in identifying any underlying triggers for your dermatitis, such as food or environmental allergies. Eliminating these triggers can often help improve symptoms.

Overall, it's important to work with a healthcare professional to create a personalized treatment plan that addresses your specific needs and concerns. They can also help monitor any potential side effects of medication and make adjustments as needed.

instruction: Hello doctor, I had seven teeth extracted today, just the roots. Anyway, over two of the teeth the dentist said there was an infection. I did not get any antibiotics, but she cleaned the area after. There is a lot of swelling in that area, and the gums are real red and like an ulcer. But not much pain. Is this normal? response:
Hello! Swelling and redness are a common post-operative symptom after tooth extraction. However, since the dentist mentioned the presence of infection in two of the teeth, it is important to monitor the area for any signs of infection.

Signs of infection include increasing pain, fever, and foul-smelling discharge. Dry socket typically presents with severe, localized pain that can radiate to the ear and may not always be associated with swelling or redness. 

If you are experiencing any unusual symptoms, I recommend contacting your dentist for an evaluation. They can diagnose and treat any complications that may arise following tooth extraction. In the meantime, continue to maintain good oral hygiene by gently brushing and flossing around the extraction sites, and follow any other post-operative instructions provided by your dentist.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 31 years old, male. My problem is when I am about to go to sleep then there is a sudden jerk. I asked my wife. I do not jerk while sleeping or in middle of sleep. It happens just when I am about to fall asleep. Suddenly a quick jerk. It happens for a couple of times then finally I go to sleep. It happens during the daytime also if after lunch I go for a nap, there is a sudden jerk when I am about to fall asleep. Once I sleep then no issues till I get up. A few months back I had this then it disappeared and now I am getting it again. CT brain was done a few months back. The report does not have it now. But it was normal. No abnormality. No diabetes, no thyroid. Normal LFT, KFT. I m taking medicine for BP. Nothing else as of now. Complete health check-up was done. I was alcoholic for a few years. If I drink and sleep, no issues. I also have a little bit of depression and anxiety due to business or work issues. Please help me out with it.
response:
Based on your description, it sounds like you may be experiencing a condition called hypnic jerks or sleep starts. These are quick, involuntary muscle spasms that usually occur as you're falling asleep. They are generally harmless and very common, affecting up to 70% of people at some point in their lives. However, anxiety and stress can exacerbate the frequency and intensity of these jerks.

It's also worth noting that excessive alcohol consumption may impact the quality of your sleep and, therefore, reduce the risk of hypnic jerks or sleep starts.

Lipid profile - triglycerides 125 mg/dL, HDL 35 mg/dL and LDL 113 mg/dL, CBC - lymphocyte 44%, serum amylase 121 IU/L, Helicobacter pylori IgA 0.45 (negative) and urine test - pus cells 3 to 4/HPF. Currently, I am taking these medicine as advised by my doctor. Zincolak one tablet twice daily, Zycolchin one tablet twice daily and Dicaris 150 mg one tablet once a day for three days.My question is that I am a healthy man with high immunity. I never get sick all around the year. How did I catch this infection? I have multiple sex partner, but I never had sex without a condom, or my condom never broke. Please give me a detailed answer and also give me advice for the treatment.
response:
Genital warts are caused by the human papilloma virus (HPV), which is highly contagious and can be spread through sexual contact. Even though you have always used a condom during sexual intercourse, there is still a risk of transmission of HPV, as the virus can be present on areas not covered by the condom, such as the scrotum, vulva, and anus.

It is also possible for the virus to remain in the body for a long time after initial infection without causing any symptoms. So it is possible that you may have contracted the virus some time ago without realizing it.

In terms of your treatment, it is important to continue taking the medication as prescribed by your doctor. Dicaris is often used to stimulate the body's immune system to fight the HPV infection. Additionally, the use of Zincolak and Zycolchin may help to boost your immune system, which can also aid in fighting the virus.

It is important to note that there is currently no cure for HPV, so treatment is aimed at managing the symptoms and reducing the risk of transmission to others. Even after warts are removed, there is always a chance of recurrence.

To reduce your risk of future infections and to prevent transmission to others, it is important to practice safe sex by using a condom during sexual intercourse and limiting your number of sexual partners. You may also want to discuss the HPV vaccine with your doctor, as it can help to protect against certain strains of the virus.

Finally, it's important to follow up with your doctor regularly to monitor your condition and ensure that treatment is working effectively.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 30 year old female, who weighs 130 lbs and 5.3 feet tall. For about 12 days, I have had consistent pain in the outer side of my breast up through my armpit. I have a tingling and slightly numb feeling in my left arm. I did not injure it, as far as I am aware. It started suddenly one morning. There is also a heaviness feeling in that whole area. When I look at the area, there is no physical change that I notice. I do not have lumps in breast or armpit that I could find.
response:
Hello! I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing pain and discomfort in your breast and armpit area. Based on your symptoms, there are a few possibilities for what could be causing this pain.

One possibility is a condition known as Costochondritis. This is an inflammation of the cartilage that connects your ribs to your breastbone. The pain can radiate into your armpit and arm, and it can feel like a sharp, stabbing pain. Treatment for this condition typically involves rest, over-the-counter pain medications, and heat or ice therapy.

Another possibility is a pinched nerve. The tingling and numbness in your arm could be a sign of nerve compression in your neck or shoulder. This can be caused by poor posture, repetitive motions, or injury. Treatment for this condition typically involves physical therapy, chiropractic care, and/or pain medications.

It's also possible that this pain could be related to breast cancer, although it's important to note that breast cancer typically does not cause pain until it's in advanced stages. However, it's always important to be proactive when it comes to your breast health. I would recommend scheduling an appointment with your healthcare provider so they can perform a physical examination and possibly order imaging tests like a mammogram or ultrasound to rule out any serious conditions.

In the meantime, you may find relief by taking over-the-counter pain medications, applying heat or ice to the affected area, and avoiding any activities that worsen your symptoms. And if you notice any new symptoms or changes to the affected area, be sure to report them to your healthcare provider right away.

I hope this information helps, and I wish you a speedy recovery.

response:
Hello, it sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). These symptoms include chest discomfort, heartburn, throat irritation, and bloating. GERD occurs when the acid from the stomach backs up into the esophagus and causes irritation. The increased burping may also be a sign of excessive gas in the digestive system.

It's important to manage GERD with diet and lifestyle modifications like eating smaller and more frequent meals, avoiding trigger foods like spicy foods, caffeine, and alcohol, and not lying down immediately after eating. Antacids or other medications can also help relieve symptoms if necessary.

However, it's important to rule out any other potential causes for your symptoms, like a heart issue. I recommend scheduling an appointment with your primary care physician to discuss your symptoms and undergo any necessary testing to ensure an accurate diagnosis.

instruction: Hello doctor,My fiancee is B positive and myself O negative. In the future, will there be any complications in my pregnancy?

If you are Rh-negative and your partner is Rh-positive, there is a risk that your baby could inherit the Rh-positive factor from your partner. This could cause your body to react as if the Rh-positive factor is foreign, potentially leading to Rh sensitization, a condition in which your body produces antibodies to attack the Rh-positive blood cells. This could cause complications in any future pregnancies, including hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), in which these antibodies attack and destroy the fetus's red blood cells.

However, there is a treatment to prevent Rh sensitization called Rh immunoglobulin (RhIg) that can be given during pregnancy and after childbirth to prevent complications.

instruction: Hello doctor,I had unprotected sex with my husband a month back and my LMP five days before that. I took Plan B pill within 10 hours of intercourse. instruction: Hello doctor,You were wonderful in allaying some health anxiety over some skin issues several months ago. So, I thought I would consult with you on another question pertaining to my son. Unfortunately, a combination of my health anxiety and the big mistake of searching online has my mind imagining the worst with regard to my son. My son is 19 years old and has no diagnosed medical issues. I noticed back when he was about eight or ten years old that he had a mark resembling a cafe au lait mark on his back, in the upper shoulder area. I had always asked the pediatrician to look at it during his yearly physicals, and they made nothing of it. Throughout the years it has grown a bit and has become darker and more rough in texture. It is probably slightly less than an inch in length and looks like a few small lesions grouped together. Again, I have brought it to the pediatrician\\s attention and he was not concerned. Three months ago, I made an appointment for him and my other son with a dermatologist for a skin exam, and I pointed out the spots which I wanted to be checked in particular. We met with the physician\\s assistant there, and my younger son had a peculiar spot I pointed out, of which the PA conducted a shave biopsy, which came back as a mildly atypical junctional nevus. For my older son, I pointed out the spot on his back/shoulder, and the PA diagnosed it as a linear epidermal nevus. She said the chances of it becoming dangerous are slim to none. It may darken throughout the years, and they will simply monitor it at yearly visits. Unfortunately, I went on to research online about epidermal nevi and of course I ran into information showing a possible link to epidermal nevus syndrome and all of its associated neurological and skeletal defects. As I said, he is 19 and has no medical issues, is extremely intelligent, etc. In your opinion, is it safe to say that I should not be concerned about those syndromes? I presume it is primarily related to the numerous and systemic epidermal nevi, which he does not have, and I would think it would have presented by now? And my last even more neurotic question. My online research led me to some information saying that a certain type of epidermal nevus could be related to a gene mutation that could be passed along to an offspring, with them having possible serious skin scaling conditions, etc. Again, he has just one solitary small epidermal nevus. No biopsy was done, as the PA did not feel it was necessary. Do you feel there is any need for me to worry about that potential genetic mutation? Thank you so much for reading my long query.
response:
Hello! I am happy to help address your concerns. Based on what you’ve described, it sounds like your son has a single linear epidermal nevus, which is a benign skin lesion. These are caused by a genetic mutation in the embryonic development of the skin and are not generally associated with any other medical conditions. While epidermal nevus syndrome can be associated with multiple and widespread epidermal nevi, your son’s single lesion does not suggest that he has this syndrome. Additionally, even if he did have epidermal nevus syndrome, the associated neurological and skeletal defects are not typically present until infancy or childhood, so it is unlikely that he would develop these conditions at his current age.

In terms of passing on a gene mutation to his offspring, the risk is generally low, especially if there is only one isolated lesion. While some epidermal nevi can be associated with specific gene mutations, this is not always the case and may not be relevant to your son’s condition. It is still a good idea to continue monitoring the lesion as recommended by his dermatologist, but there is no need to worry about him passing on any significant genetic risk to his offspring.

I hope this information helps to ease your concerns. Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns.

If you were experiencing weakness in your breathing muscles, you would likely notice difficulty with exercise and running. Overall, it sounds like you are on the right track by taking medication for anxiety and working with your doctors to rule out any underlying medical issues. Keep up the good work and don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare team if you continue to experience any concerning symptoms.

instruction: Hello doctor,Sometimes, when I am doing stuff, my vision makes it seem like there is a white haze, like heaven, I guess. Like everything has a white haze light. response:

However, some people may experience only the visual symptoms without the headache.

When you experience this white haze in your vision, do you experience any other symptoms such as headache, nausea, or vomiting? If so, these symptoms may be related to the ocular migraine.

I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with an ophthalmologist or a neurologist for a comprehensive eye exam and neurological evaluation to rule out any underlying conditions that may be causing your symptoms. It is also important to discuss your medical history and any underlying conditions you may have with your doctor.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 63 year old male. I had polio affected right leg, but have been leading a normal life since then. Recently, I developed pain in the right thigh joint, but able to walk normally. In some positions, it is painful. I have got my MRI study of the hip joint. The report is enclosed herewith. The doctor has suggested physiotherapy IFT and IPT for 10 days and put on medication for seven days. As I am working, he advised 10 days rest. The medicines are Tolagin 4 mg X1 for seven days, Miofree 8 mg once daily for seven days and Pantodac 40 mg twice daily for seven days.
response: Hello,\n\nBased on the MRI report, there seems to be evidence of osteoarthritis in the hip joint, which could be causing the pain. Physiotherapy and medication are appropriate treatment options for managing the pain and improving joint mobility. Tolagin is an NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug) that helps reduce inflammation and pain. Miofree is a muscle relaxant that can help alleviate muscle spasms that may contribute to pain. Pantodac is a proton pump inhibitor that reduces stomach acid production and is commonly used to treat acid reflux and gastritis. It is important to follow your doctor's instructions and complete the prescribed course of treatment. Resting for 10 days may also help in reducing the pain and promoting healing. However, if the pain persists or worsens, you should seek medical attention again for further evaluation and management. Overall, managing osteoarthritis requires a comprehensive approach that includes lifestyle modifications, physical therapy, medication, and in some cases, surgery.
