instruction: Hello doctor,I am an 18-year-old female. I have a cold with chest pain, fatigue and difficulty breathing for three days up till now, without physically consulting a doctor. I have had pneumonia last year and I am afraid that I might get again as I am starting to show some symptoms of pneumonia. Should I be concerned?
response:
Hello,

As per your symptoms, you could have a respiratory infection that could be pneumonia or bronchitis, or it could be a severe form of cold.

Chest pain, fatigue and difficulty breathing are some of the symptoms of pneumonia. Without examining you physically, it is difficult to assess your condition.

Therefore, it would be better if you consult a doctor as soon as possible. Your doctor may need to evaluate your symptoms and perform a physical exam to determine a diagnosis and provide you with the appropriate treatment plan.

Please seek medical attention immediately to get timely treatment and avoid any complications.

Please keep yourself well hydrated and take rest until you see your doctor.

Hope this helps.

instruction: Hi doctor.I had Pantocid HP after doctor advice and had loose motion 4-5 times. For stopping loose motion what shall I do? For past six days I am taking Pantocid HP kit. No problem except loose motion of about 5-6 times and some weakness.I am taking Bifilac HP one tablet daily and a vitamin capsule. How long loose motion will happen as it is a 14 days course. I know this is a side effect.Can I take electrol powder (ORS) and coconut water? Should I follow any food restriction except spicy food?
response:
Hello,

Loose motion can be a side effect of taking Pantocid HP kit. You are already taking Bifilac HP which is good for your gut health. You can also take Electral powder or ORS to prevent dehydration due to loose motion. You can drink coconut water and other fluids to keep yourself hydrated. For food, avoid spicy and oily food as much as possible. Follow a bland diet consisting of boiled vegetables, rice, and dal. You can also have banana and curd which are good for gut health.

Usually, loose motion stops in a few days once the body adjusts to the medication. But if it persists for a longer time or you experience any other symptoms like fever, blood in stools or severe abdominal pain, you should consult your doctor.

instruction: Hello doctor,Something broke off from one of my teeth, and I would like to know what was it that broke and what I should do about it (if anything). I think it might have been tartar or cementum, but I do not know. They are hard and off whitish (a little yellowing). They are the same as that material that appears roughly along the bottom edges of my lower incisors. I think they are either tartar or cementum, but I do not know. Please let me know what you think they are and what my options are.
response:
Hello! It's difficult to say exactly what broke off from your tooth without examining it in person. However, based on your description, it is possible that it was a piece of tartar buildup or dental cementum. Tartar is a hard, yellow or brown substance that forms on teeth when plaque hardens, while cementum is a similar hard tissue that covers the root of teeth.

If the piece that broke off was small and did not cause any pain or sensitivity, there may not be an urgent need for treatment. However, it's always a good idea to have a dentist take a look and provide their professional opinion. They may recommend a cleaning to remove any remaining tartar buildup and smooth the tooth surface, or they may suggest repairing the tooth if there is significant damage.

If the broken piece was large or the tooth is painful or sensitive, it's important to schedule an appointment with your dentist as soon as possible to prevent any further damage or infection. They may suggest a filling, crown, or other restoration to repair the tooth.

In the meantime, be sure to continue practicing good oral hygiene habits like brushing twice a day, flossing daily, and using an antiseptic mouthwash to prevent any additional issues from arising.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old healthy male. Last month, I had an unfortunate sexual exposure (condom\\s head broke off). I quickly pulled out and washed the genital area with a bathing soap. After few days, I started having a slight itching sensation in the penis. I visited a urologist and he asked me to undergo urine routine and culture tests. The urine culture report did not show any bacterial growth, but the urine routine showed some abnormalities. I have attached those two reports. On subsequent visit, the doctor prescribed me a 10 day antibiotic course (Microdox LBX 100 mg) to be taken twice a day. In addition to that, he also asked me to wash the penis with Betadine Povidone-iodine solution twice a day. The antibiotic course got over two days back. But since then, I have been noticing a slight burning sensation after passing urine, especially during morning and afternoon hours. Today, there is a slight pain in the penis. I checked the area, but did not find any abnormality. Please help in resolving this issue.
response:
Based on your description, it sounds like you may have a urinary tract infection or a sexually transmitted infection. Even though the urine culture did not show any bacterial growth, the abnormal urine routine suggests that there may be some underlying issue. It is possible that the antibiotics you took may have suppressed the bacterial growth that was causing the infection, but didn't completely eliminate it. 

I recommend that you return to your urologist for a follow-up appointment and inform them about your current symptoms. They may need to perform additional tests or prescribe a different antibiotic to treat any residual infection. It is also possible that you may need to be tested for sexually transmitted infections, as some of them can cause similar symptoms. 

In the meantime, it's important that you continue to practice good hygiene and avoid any sexual activity until you have resolved the issue. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids to help flush out any potential infection and avoid irritants such as harsh soaps or bubble baths that can further irritate the area. If your symptoms worsen or you develop a fever, it's important that you seek medical attention right away.

instruction: Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. I have tried almost all SSRIs, and SNRIs and neither of them have worked for me (for the last 2 1/2 years). I believe that I have treatment-resistant depression because all the medicines are not working. Currently, I am taking 20 mg of Paroxetine (although I already took 40 mg a few months ago, so I already increased the dose as well), 900 mg of Lithium and 1.5 mg of Risperidone. What should I do?
response:
I'm sorry to hear that you have been struggling with treatment-resistant depression. It can be frustrating when medications do not provide relief from symptoms. It sounds like you are on a combination of antidepressants, mood stabilizers, and antipsychotics. However, since they have not been effective, I suggest you speak with your psychiatrist about alternative treatment options.

One option you may want to consider is psychotherapy. There are different forms of therapy that have been shown to be effective for depression, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dialectical-behavioral therapy (DBT), and interpersonal therapy (IPT). These therapies aim to help you understand and change negative patterns of thinking and behavior that contribute to depression.

Another potential option is transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), which uses a magnetic field to stimulate nerve cells in the brain. TMS has been found to have some effectiveness in treating treatment-resistant depression.

Lastly, your psychiatrist may recommend different medications that target different neurotransmitters or receptors in the brain. Some examples include atypical antipsychotics such as quetiapine or aripiprazole, or mood stabilizers such as lamotrigine or valproate.

It is important to work closely with your psychiatrist to develop a personalized treatment plan and monitor for any potential side effects.

instruction: Hello doctor,My bottom teeth were drilled for a root canal but after drilling doctor told that my teeth have a split and he filled that hole with a cavity. From the past one year, my gum was swollen and bad smell is coming out from that teeth. From the past one month, I have had bumps on my back of tongue and white coat. Is this a cause of diseased teeth? Currently, I am on Esoz 40 and Telmekind H.
response:
Hello,

Yes, your diseased tooth could be causing your swollen gum and bad breath. In some cases, when there is a split in the tooth, the filling alone may not be enough to fix the problem. There could be some infected or dead tissue inside the tooth that is causing these symptoms.

The bumps on the back of your tongue and the white coat could also be indicative of an infection or inflammation in your mouth.

I would recommend that you follow up with your dentist to have them examine your teeth and gums to see if there is any infection that needs to be addressed. You may also want to see your doctor if your symptoms persist after visiting the dentist.

In the meantime, continue taking your medications as prescribed, and maintain good oral hygiene practices such as brushing and flossing twice a day. Additionally, use an antiseptic mouthwash to rinse your mouth after brushing.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 30-year-old woman. I am having OCD since I was 12 years old. I have a strong fear of an event that happened a couple of years ago when a psychiatrist told me that I have a borderline disorder and have no fantasy. I was trying to ask her for years to say me the opposite as a compulsion. She refused to do that, I am not sure if it is because she did not want to change her opinion or it is because she did not want to satisfy my compulsion. My mother was encouraging me to do these kinds of compulsions as she thought it is going to get worse. It was a bad thing as she was validating my fears in this way. I just realized these things now so I started to confront my fears about what the psychiatrist said to me. But I ran into another one which is about what if my mother is right and if I am confronting my fears it is going to get worse. What do you think?
response:
Hello! I'm sorry to hear that you've been struggling with OCD for so long. It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of uncertainty and anxiety related to what happened with the psychiatrist and your fear of having borderline personality disorder.

It's important to remember that compulsions, such as seeking reassurance, can actually worsen anxiety and OCD symptoms over time. It can be challenging to resist the urge to seek certainty, but doing so can help break the cycle of anxious thoughts and behaviors.

Regarding your fear that confronting your fears will make things worse, this is another form of uncertainty that OCD thrives on. It's important to recognize that while facing your fears might be uncomfortable in the short-term, it's ultimately the best way to overcome them.

You might consider seeking treatment from a mental health professional who specializes in OCD, as they can provide you with tools and techniques to manage your symptoms more effectively. Strategies such as exposure and response prevention (ERP) have been shown to be effective in reducing anxiety related to OCD.

Remember, recovery is possible with the right treatment and support. Don't hesitate to reach out for help.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 34 year old female. I have been having terrible anxiety the past month. I wake up feeling very uneasy and nervous. Almost shaky. I also feel like I literally cannot breathe. I have to take deep breaths constantly. I went to an urgent care and they tested for a blood clot in the lungs, but I was cleared. My doctor put me on Lexapro two months ago and I stopped taking it. But then the anxiety got so bad that I started again on it two weeks ago. My fear is that there is something wrong with my heart. I have had this before and chest pain. So, I have been to two different cardiologists. We did stress tests and echoes. I am afraid these doctors are blowing me off because I am active. Please advise.
response:
I'm sorry to hear about your struggles with anxiety. It's important to know that anxiety can often mimic symptoms of heart problems, such as shortness of breath and chest pain. It's good that you've already had cardiac workup done and the tests came back normal. 

It's also important to know that anxiety can be a chronic condition and can take time to improve. It's not uncommon for people to need to try different medications or combinations of therapies before finding what works best for them. Stopping and starting medication can also contribute to the severity of anxiety symptoms. 

I would recommend following up with your doctor about your continuing symptoms and discussing any further treatments or changes to your current regimen. Additionally, therapy can be a great addition to medication in treating anxiety. It can provide coping skills and strategies for managing and reducing symptoms. 

Overall, it's important to take care of your physical and emotional well-being. Keep advocating for yourself and seeking the help you need.

instruction: Dear doctor,I am a 21 year old male. I feel quite sad and depressed. I do not even want to perform daily routine. My life is monotonous. I get a lot of negative thoughts. I am so lazy and feel like I do not want to live. I am weak and I lack concentration. I do not feel like going out of my house. Suggest treatment for the same.
response:
Dear patient,

From your description, it appears that you might be experiencing depression. Depression is a medical condition that requires treatment. It is characterized by feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and disinterest in activities that one once enjoyed. It is important to seek medical attention promptly to avoid worsening of symptoms.

The following are some suggestions for treatment

instruction: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.
response:
Dear patient, 

Left bundle branch block (LBBB) is a condition characterized by a delay or blockage of electrical impulses that control the heartbeat, which can cause the ventricles to contract out of sync, leading to an abnormal ECG pattern. 

In general, stress testing (echocardiograms, stress EKG or nuclear stress tests) is used to evaluate the presence of coronary artery disease (CAD), which could be a concern in patients with LBBB. However, stress echocardiograms are generally considered less sensitive and specific than nuclear stress tests. 

That being said, stress echocardiograms can still provide valuable information about the heart function and possible signs of CAD. So, it is not entirely true that stress echocardiograms are irrelevant in patients with LBBB. However, nuclear stress testing is generally considered to be the gold standard for CAD screening in patients with LBBB, although it does involve exposure to a small amount of radiation. 

You seem to be taking good care of your health by exercising regularly, and it's great to hear that you have been following up with a cardiologist to monitor your heart health. Your high HDL and low triglycerides are favorable, but your high cholesterol levels could increase your risk of CAD, especially given your family history. 

Therefore, I suggest discussing with your doctor the possibility of undergoing a nuclear stress test to evaluate your CAD risk. This would provide you with more accurate results than a stress echocardiogram, and it would enable you to get a clearer picture of your heart's health. 

Finally, I would like to emphasize the importance of continuing to follow up with your doctor regularly, especially given your family history of heart disease. Keep up the great work with your healthy lifestyle practices, and stay proactive about your heart health.

instruction: Hi doctor,I had a c-section with my first pregnancy 19 years ago. I have fallen in love with a wonderful man who does not have kids. I and my fiance have been discussing and are planning to have a baby. I am concerned if I am able to have a VBAC delivery with my second pregnancy since my first pregnancy resulted in an emergency C-section. Also, I am 48. What are the risks of pregnancy in women over 40?
response:
Hello! While attempting a VBAC (vaginal birth after cesarean) is a possibility after a previous c-section, there are potential risks involved. The probability of a successful vaginal delivery after cesarean is largely dependent on the specific circumstances surrounding the previous c-section. Many factors can impact this decision, including the reason for your previous c-section, the type of incision made during your previous surgery, and any additional medical conditions.

That being said, age needs to be taken into account when planning a pregnancy. After the age of 40, the risk of fertility issues, miscarriage, and complications during pregnancy increases. Women over the age of 40 also have a higher likelihood of developing gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, placenta previa or abruption, and other medical conditions. 

It is important to schedule a consultation with your obstetrician and discuss your individual health and medical history to determine the best course of action for a successful pregnancy.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have a recurrent sore throat for the past seven months. I cannot drink, swallow, and my tongue is covered with a white layer. I have a dust allergy. I have a mild fever that goes to high fever as the time passes. There is malaise. I have vomiting often after I swallow. It is like a viscous sputum that blocks food from entering into the food canal. This time, I have swollen lymph nodes in my neck. The doctor examined me and told me there is no tonsillitis. I am taking Levofloxacin, Azithromycin, Ofloxacin, and Amoxicillin.
response:
Hello, I understand your concern. Recurrent sore throat, difficulty drinking and swallowing, white coating on the tongue, fever, and vomiting can be symptoms of various conditions such as tonsillitis, strep throat, pharyngitis, or even an allergic reaction. Based on your description, it is evident that the antibiotics that you have been taking are not effective in treating the underlying condition.

I suggest you to visit an ENT specialist, they can perform a thorough examination, which may include throat culture and allergy testing to identify the cause of your symptoms. Treatment may include an antihistamine, steroid medications, or other medications depending on the diagnosis.

In the meantime, you can try the following remedies to ease your symptoms

instruction: Hello doctor,My wife has lung cancer PD-L1. I need your advice regarding the continuation of this therapy. Docetaxel and Nintedanib are suggested. I think it is too heavy. I would prefer immunotherapy, if possible.
response:
Hello,

I'm sorry to hear about your wife's diagnosis. The treatment plan for lung cancer patients often depends on the stage of the disease, the specific type of tumor, and other individual factors. Immunotherapy is a good option for patients with PD-L1 positive lung cancer, as it helps to enhance the immune system's ability to fight cancer cells.

However, in some cases, chemotherapy may still be recommended as the first-line treatment, particularly if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. Docetaxel is a common chemotherapy drug that has been shown to be effective against lung cancer, and Nintedanib is a targeted therapy that can be used in combination to improve results.

If your wife is not able to tolerate the chemotherapy, immunotherapy may be considered as a treatment option. Your oncologist will be the best person to advise you on the best treatment plan for your wife's specific condition. Ask them about the benefits and risks of the different therapies and make an informed decision together.

I hope this helps, and I wish you and your wife all the best.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have had a terrible cough for weeks due to the flu. I decided to try Delsym 12 hour cough. It helped immensely, but the second day when I had it, I noticed a bit of restlessness and light sensitivity. I waited to take another dose and when I did take another dose, I took half of the recommended dose for adults. That was at 10 pm last night. Now, at almost 2 pm the next day and I am experiencing odd side effects. Sweaty palms, a bit of confusion, loss of attention, and light sensitivity. It feels like my eyes are dilated, but does not appear they are. Every day I take 20 mg of Vyvanse and 300 mg of Wellbutrin.
response:
Hello! I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing these symptoms.

It is possible that the combination of your medication and the Delsym may be causing these side effects. Delsym contains the active ingredient dextromethorphan, which is processed by the liver and can interact with certain medications. In particular, it may increase the effectiveness of medications that affect the central nervous system, such as Vyvanse and Wellbutrin.

The symptoms you are experiencing could be related to a potential interaction between the medications you are taking and the Delsym. I would recommend contacting your doctor or pharmacist as soon as possible to discuss these symptoms and any potential interactions between your medications. They can advise you on the best course of action and whether you should discontinue the use of the Delsym.

In the meantime, it may be helpful to avoid driving or operating heavy machinery until your symptoms have resolved. Also, make sure to stay hydrated and get plenty of rest.

instruction: Hi doctor, I am 28 years old and weigh 72 kgs. I am not married or pregnant.Recently, I have been having a problem of breast leakage and during intercourse, my boyfriend has also shared the same concern.It is embarrassing & alarming at the same time. What could be the reason?
response: Breast leakage or discharge can occur in women who are not pregnant or breastfeeding. There are several possible causes of this, such as hormonal imbalances, certain medication side effects, breast infections, or benign or malignant breast conditions. It is essential to be evaluated by a healthcare provider to determine the underlying cause of your breast leakage. They may also order some tests or imaging studies such as a mammogram or breast ultrasound to investigate further. It is recommended that you make an appointment to see your healthcare provider to address this concern.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am undergoing Q-switched laser treatment along with the use of Hydroquinone to treat my melasma. However, I would like to know if the use of stem cell creams can worsen the melasma by encouraging the growth of melanin? Currently, I am taking Tranexamic acid, Cipramil, Valdoxan.
response:
There isn't enough research to determine whether stem cell creams can worsen melasma or encourage the growth of melanin. However, it's important to note that some stem cell creams contain additional ingredients that may irritate the skin and make melasma worse.

Regarding your current medications, Tranexamic acid is known to be effective in treating melasma by reducing the production of melanin in the skin. Cipramil and Valdoxan aren't typically used to treat melasma.

It's important to follow your dermatologist's guidance regarding your treatment plan and to inform them of any new products you plan to use on your skin.

instruction: Hello doctor, For ten years, my husband has been successfully using an extended wear bandage contact lens (monthly wear) to control the pain of aphakic bullous keratopathy in one eye. About seven months ago, he had an episode of foreign body pain in the eye which the contact lens could not control. His optometrist changed the type of lens after remarking that the lens appeared tight. Although the painful sensations have decreased, they are still present with more of a sore feeling now. His ophthalmologist suggested that he discontinue the Azopt drops he had been using in case the preservative was causing some corneal toxicity. His eye pressure without the drops has read at 18 and 20 on separate occasions, but he does have corneal edema which may affect the measurement. He has had high pressure in that eye previously, but it was mostly lowered by Cyclodiode treatment some eight years ago. The consultant said he had left him on the Azopt drops just as a precaution. My query is that if the bandage lens has worked so well for pain management for 10 years is it possible that it can continue to work? And if the Azopt drops and their preservative had caused some toxic reaction seven months ago, could that still be causing him to feel the discomfort? His consultant suggested out that he could have the eye removed to control the pain, but as he has what he feels is some slight, useful vision in that eye, he does not want to take such a drastic and life-changing step. In fact, he wants to pursue the least invasive course of action to relieve the pain he is getting. I would appreciate any advice you could give as he is in quite a bit of pain.
response:
Hello,

It is certainly possible that the bandage lens can continue to work for pain management in your husband's case. However, it may be worth considering whether the change in lens type could be contributing to his ongoing discomfort. It may be worth discussing with his optometrist if there are any other lens options to try.

Regarding the Azopt drops, it is possible that the preservative could have caused some corneal toxicity and contributed to your husband's discomfort. However, it is difficult to determine the extent of this without any further examination or testing. If your husband was experiencing foreign body pain, it is also possible that there was an underlying issue such as a corneal abrasion or infection that could be contributing to the discomfort. 

It may be beneficial to have your husband's ophthalmologist re-evaluate his corneal edema and intraocular pressure, as well as perform a thorough evaluation of his eye to rule out any underlying causes of his ongoing discomfort. There may be other pain management treatments that can be tried before considering more invasive options such as eye removal. 

I would recommend discussing these options with his ophthalmologist and optometrist, and seeking their guidance on the best course of action to relieve his pain.

instruction: Hello doctor,I have an anal fissure. I am taking homeopathy for the past 25 days. It worked for the first 20 days, but for the past five days, my pain has increased significantly. Is it homeopathy aggravation or something else?
response: Hello! As an AI language model, I am not qualified to provide a medical diagnosis or advice. instruction: Hello doctor,I am 30 years old male with HTN (Telmisartan 49 mg and CTD 6.25 mg) for past six years with a body weight of 80 kg. For some days I have noticed froth in urine and facial puffiness. I want your suggestion. My RFT was normal but I have not checked my urine for protein or USG abdomen. Can you please guide me regarding further management?
response:
Hello,

Based on the symptoms you described, it is important to check for proteinuria in your urine as it could be a sign of kidney damage. I would recommend that you get a urine test done (24-hour urinary protein) and an ultrasound of the abdomen to check for any abnormalities in the kidney or liver. 

Additionally, facial puffiness can sometimes be a sign of fluid retention, so your doctor may prescribe a diuretic medication to help remove excess fluid from your body. 

It is important to continue taking your blood pressure medications, as well as following a low-sodium diet and exercising regularly. If any abnormalities are detected on your tests, your doctor may recommend further tests or refer you to a specialist for further evaluation and management. 

Please make an appointment with your doctor as soon as possible to address these symptoms and to ensure the best possible management of your health.

instruction: Hello doctor,I am 30 years old, female. I get cough problem during year end which never goes till next 3 to 4 months. I get a little bit of relaxation by medicine but not completely and again next year I feel the same problem. I have gone for X-ray, etc., and everything was fine.
response: Hello,\n\nBased on your symptoms and X-ray report, it is possible that you are experiencing seasonal allergies or asthma. These conditions can cause persistent coughing and require ongoing management. I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with an allergist or a pulmonologist to get a thorough evaluation and appropriate treatment plan. In the meantime, to alleviate your symptoms, make sure to avoid triggers like dust, pollen, and pollution, and consider using a humidifier to keep your airways moist. Also, try to maintain good hygiene practices like washing your hands frequently, and covering your mouth when coughing or sneezing to prevent the spread of infections.

instruction: Hello doctor,I had a CBC (complete blood count) done yesterday and it came back with elevated WBC of 13500, with neutrophils 9000 (more or less), ESR 36, and close to normal lymphocytes. My urine sample was negative. I had a severe eye infection that lasted about 10 days and started clearing up really nicely yesterday. When I had the blood work done, I was crying for an hour due to unrelated massive stress factors. I have severe anxiety and I am going through a rough time, I am hardly ever at ease. I am mentioning this because I read stress can be a factor.I am worried because my levels are elevated and I show no signs of infection apart from the eye (which still has a little pus). I do not go out due to COVID-19 at all. Food is delivered and handled in a very safe way, packages are disinfected and I have no contact with anyone. I am puzzled as to where an infection could come from. My doctor thinks it is a bacterial infection and has put me on antibiotics. I am very worried about cancer. Should I be?
response:
Hello!

I understand your concerns and I will try to help you.

An elevated WBC count with neutrophilia (increased neutrophils) is usually a sign of bacterial infection or inflammation. A high ESR may also indicate inflammation. It is good that your urine sample was negative, because that would have indicated a urinary tract infection that could have caused the elevated WBC count. 

Stress can indeed cause a temporary increase in WBC count, but it usually returns to normal within a few hours or days. It is unlikely that your stress alone would cause such a persistent increase in WBC count.

If your eye infection is bacterial, then that could be the source of the infection. However, if you have no other symptoms or signs of infection, then it is puzzling as to where the infection could be coming from. 

Cancer would not typically cause an isolated increase in WBC count without other signs or symptoms. 

I would recommend that you follow your doctor's advice and take the antibiotics as prescribed, to treat the possible bacterial infection. You can also discuss with your doctor if any further testing, such as a culture or imaging, would be helpful in determining the cause of the elevated WBC count.

I hope this helps! Feel free to ask any further questions.

instruction: Hello doctor,My daughter who is 2.8 years old cried hard before two weeks and developed a hoarse voice the next day. It subsided in about three days. Before a week, I remember her throwing tantrums and crying hard for every small thing and again developed a hoarse voice. I gave warm water and honey, and it has subsided a lot.Sometimes her voice sounds normal, and when she screams or cries, I can still feel her voice is a little hoarse. Is this hoarseness due to crying or could be any other infection? I read that hoarseness could occur due to cancer. I am a paranoid mother who gets scared after reading the stuff. She does not have any cold, cough and eats normally.In spite of her hoarse voice, she is taking ice creams and cold stuff. If the hoarseness is due to any serious medical condition, would she have any accompanying symptoms? My main concern is cancer. What would be the symptoms of laryngeal cancer other than hoarseness? She is a very adamant kid and still screams if things do not go her way. Suggest remedies to get rid of hoarseness. Please remove my anxiety towards cancer.
response:
Hello! It sounds like your daughter's hoarseness is most likely due to the episodes of crying and tantrums she's been having, which can strain the voice and lead to temporary hoarseness. It's unlikely to be due to cancer, especially since she has no other symptoms or risk factors for that.

In addition to warm liquids and honey, you can also try having your daughter rest her voice by avoiding yelling or excessive talking. Humidifiers or steam inhalation may also be helpful in soothing the vocal cords. If the hoarseness persists for more than a week, or if you notice any other symptoms or concerns, it's best to bring her to a pediatrician or an ENT specialist for an evaluation.

Laryngeal cancer in children is extremely rare, and most cases occur in older adults who have a history of smoking or alcohol use. Symptoms may include persistent hoarseness or changes in the voice, difficulty swallowing, throat pain, or a lump in the neck. However, these symptoms are also common in other more common conditions, so it's important not to jump to conclusions and instead seek medical advice if you have any concerns.

instruction: Hi doctor,I am a 43-year-old female. I have bloating and loose stools for the past two days. There is no cramping and vomiting. I do not have any other issues. Please advice.
response:
Hello! I am an AI language model and not a doctor. However, I can provide general information.

Bloating and loose stools can be caused by many things, including food intolerances, infections, or stress. It is important to monitor your symptoms and see if they improve on their own.

instruction: Hello doctor,Diagnosed with varicocele grade 2. I have a lot of queries. Can it be treated? Will varicocele affect my sexual life? response:
Hello! 

1. Varicocele can be treated. Treatment options include surgery, embolization, or observation. Surgery is the most common treatment and is usually successful. 

2. Varicocele can affect your sexual life, but it depends on the severity of the condition. Varicoceles can sometimes cause discomfort or pain during sexual activity. However, treating the condition can alleviate these symptoms. 

3. Varicocele can potentially lead to infertility, but it is controversial. It is estimated that up to 40% of men with infertility have a varicocele. However, not all men with varicocele will have infertility issues, and not all men with infertility will have a varicocele. 

4. Sexual activity should not complicate your varicocele. However, if you experience discomfort or pain during sexual activity, it is recommended that you discuss it with your doctor. 

5. You do not need to avoid sexual intercourse due to varicocele. 

6. You can go to the gym, but it is recommended that you avoid heavy lifting and strenuous exercise for a few weeks after surgery to allow for proper healing.

instruction: Hi doctor,I have just received results back from a blood test that says my red blood cell count is quite high. I am a 35-year-old female and I am a smoker (between 4 to 7 a day). A high red blood cell count can be caused by a variety of factors, including smoking, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), sleep apnea, heart problems, kidney diseases, dehydration, and certain medications. Smoking causes the body to produce more red blood cells to carry oxygen to the tissues, which can lead to a higher red blood cell count.

Your symptoms, including headaches, dizziness, nausea, fatigue, and itchiness, could be related to a high red blood cell count, but they could also be caused by other factors. A miscarriage can also cause some of these symptoms, so it's important to discuss your history with your doctor.

Quitting smoking is an important step to take to reduce the risk of further complications associated with a high red blood cell count. However, it's also important to identify any underlying medical conditions and monitor your red blood cell count over time. Your doctor may recommend additional tests, such as a lung function test or sleep study, to determine whether any additional treatments or lifestyle changes are necessary.

If you experience any sudden or severe symptoms, such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or difficulty breathing, seek emergency medical attention right away.

I hope this information helps you.

instruction: Hello doctor,I had a question about the ketone diet. I honestly do not understand the benefits of a ketone diet, what are they? Is a ketone diet good for those who are diabetic?
response:
Hello! The main benefit of a ketogenic diet is its ability to help the body enter a state of ketosis, in which it shifts from burning glucose (from carbohydrates) to burning fats for fuel. This can lead to weight loss, improved blood sugar control, and potentially other health benefits such as improved cholesterol and triglycerides levels.

For people with diabetes, a ketogenic diet may be helpful in managing blood sugar levels, as it typically involves severely limiting carbohydrate intake. However, it is important to work with a healthcare provider and a registered dietitian to ensure that the diet is tailored to individual needs and does not lead to any adverse effects.

It is also important to note that a ketogenic diet is not appropriate for everyone, and should only be considered under the guidance of a healthcare professional.

response:
Hello. In PCOS, ovarian cysts are a common occurrence. The pain that you are experiencing on your left side could be due to several reasons, and one of them could be referred pain. Referred pain means that the pain is felt in a location different from where it originates. In your case, the cyst in your right ovary could be pressing on a nerve or tissue that is causing pain on your left side.  It's also possible that the pain on your left side is due to a separate issue or condition. 

As for your question, yes, the pain could be due to the cyst. Ovarian cysts can cause pain and discomfort, especially if they grow and put pressure on surrounding tissues.

It's important to follow up with your doctor to determine the underlying cause of your pain and discuss possible treatment options. Depending on the size and type of cyst, your doctor may recommend watchful waiting, medications, or surgery.
